That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the government for its budget waste and mismanagement, and wrong priorities which have resulted in: (1) a costly Medicare ‘safety net’ which does not protect families from increasing health costs and declining levels of bulk billing; (2) inadequate funding and higher fees for students seeking access to higher education; (3) a growing number of families who are financially squeezed and trying to balance work and family; and (4) 500,000 Australians waiting up to five years to get their teeth fixed”. the Main Committee that it was agreed in the House that a general cognate debate be allowed with the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 covering the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 20032004 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004. 2003-2004 and the cognate bills. On Tuesday, 20 January the Prime Minister carried out a diversionary tactic, not surprisingly, which became not just a diversionary tactic but a divisive tactic by attacking public schools, teachers in those schools and, by implication, students and their families in those schools with his disgraceful attack on the so-called valueless systems in our state schools and the provision of antiseptic values. He charged that our schools are filled with politically correct teachers and that our curriculum is charged with political correctness. On 26 January on a Current Affair, Ray Martin asked the Prime Minister: Why did you begin this year with such divisive comments about public education? John Howard replied: Nothing divisive. I was just asked a question as to why I thought an increasing number of people were wanting to send their children to independent schools and I gave some of the reasons. I didn’t make a generalised attack on government schools. Ray Martin went on: What did you mean though ... in terms of ‘antiseptic’ and what are the values missing from government schools? The Prime Minister said: MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Sidebottom (Braddon) (4.05 P.m.)
theText: I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3)Well, you know, people come to me and say all sorts of things. AndI mentioned some of them. I don’t have time on this programme to go through all of them and I’ll develop some of the things during the week. Ray Martin asked: It looks like you’ve thrown a bit of a cracker and then stepped away. The Prime Minister replied: No, no. I never throw crackers and step away. I mean ... what I said I meant. Don’t think for a minute that I’m stepping away from what I said. Ray Martin then asked: What’s antiseptic mean? The Prime Minister said, ‘Well, you know’ and on it went. Ray Martin finally said: But don’t you seriously think that government schools don’t have values? The Prime Minister replied that he did not have time to go through it. SoI spent some of my own time to find out what the Prime Minister meant by valueless schools, by political correctness in the curriculum and by the provision of an antiseptic atmosphere in our schools. I looked for proof. One of the values that I think is very important is that you provide evidence in a reasoned debate for your argument. Has the Prime Minister said anything since? Not a single word. There has not been a single word to substantiate the disgraceful charges that he levels: ‘Some people talk to me and I have to report what they say.’ We can all bet what happened. He called the reporters in and said, ‘Listen, cop this. It might divert attention away from the fact university places are not available to students.’ So it is about diverting attention, making education divisive and using it as a diversionary tactic from the higher education agenda. Of course, on cue, came the Prime Minister’s willing acolytes, who are on the Right on anything dealing with so-called values in public education. Of course, the member for Gippsland popped in with some really edifying comments that education in public schools is valuefree, hostile or, at best, apathetic to Australian heritage and values-whatever that meant. At this stage, the member for Gippsland was the acting federal education minister. Then there was the member for Warringah-the boxing monk-but you would expect that. I am sad to say that the member for Herbert rushed in with his unsubstantiated comments and Senator Lightfoot rushed in, as he does, to protect the Prime Minister from anyone who might possibly be harassing his presence or his views. But it did cause division, not just in the community but also in his own party. That is not something the Prime Minister is used to, but we have seen examples of it more recently. It caused division because enlightened persons such as the members for Adelaide, Hindmarsh, Pearce and Macquarie came out and basically said, ‘This is arrant nonsense.’ To claim that public schools are valueless is the same as saying that private schools are valueless-arrant nonsense. They at least were prepared to stand up publicly and say so. So it was not just the superannuation meeting or the Clarke report on veteran entitlements that saw divisions in the Liberal Party caucus room coming to the fore; the same applied to this comment on public education by the Prime Minister. I acknowledge the comments by those members of the coalition who were prepared to stand up to the statements of arrant nonsense by the Prime Minister and those other members. I mentioned. MAIN COMMITTEE I thought it was best reflected by the cartoonists-as is their wont. In the Australian on 20 January 2004 there was a cartoon which I know I cannot show at the moment but I will try to describe it. It showed our Prime Minister with a sign behind him saying, ‘Howard’s way-a federal government nation-building project.’ In front of him is an earthquake fault line, and there is a little sign on the other side of the highway heading off in the distance saying, ‘Divided country’. That is exactly what those comments did. They were needlessly hurtful, silly comments not substantiated by evidence. It was not just me who was disgusted by those comments. Many people throughout Australia-even principals of private schools-thought what a worthless debate the Prime Minister had brought about. I attended a number of school excellence ceremonies and of course the Prime Minister’s comments featured at those ceremonies. People were disgusted and hurt by the comments. I would like to quote from an address at an evening of excellence at one of the schools in my electorate of Braddon-and a very good school at that. The principal said: I felt that tonight, of all nights, I couldn’t let their comments go unanswered or our students and parents think that the schools that have produced the wonderful young people we will see tonight are in any way sub-standard or without values. Fancy having to have this discussion in the first place. The principal went on to analyse why they believed the Prime Minister made those comments and said: If that is the casethat is, to bring about division and diversionI thought I would take the time tonight to explain the values that I think underlie the academic and personal relationships we have at (our school) and ask the question ‘if not these values, then which?’ The Prime Minister was asked several times: ‘What values are you talking about? What values don’t exist in our public schools that you believe should exist?’ Of course he did not answer. The principal went on: Our primary concerns ... are, I think, fivefold and they relate closely to Howard Gardner’s view of schools. We are concerned with the truth. Not the truth that gave us ‘children overboard’, ‘weapons of mass destruction’ and now ‘valueless schools’-but how we determine what is false or misleading and, importantly, what we do with that knowledge. Secondly, we are concerned with beauty and it is from this concern we model not just our arts curriculum but our deep concern and empathy for the environment and the planet, surely the most beautiful and fragile of things that we have in our care. Thirdly, we are concerned with morality-what is good and what is right. This is not the morality of politics but the morality of how people should be treated and treat others. He goes on to say, fourthly: We are concerned with educational excellence, not only of the academic elite but of all students. This comes from our deeply held views that teachers make a difference and all students can learn. Finally, we are concerned, in State schools with equality. We take everyone into our state school system. He says that at their school: … alongside the students you will meet tonightand it was a night of excellence, I would remind youwith TE scores as good as any in the country, you will find blind students, Downs Syndrome students, homeless students, students with mental illness and physical impairment. You will find students who are poor, students who are rich, students who are black and students who are white. In this melting pot, whose cultural values are the ones we must follow and explore and support? You and I know that we MAIN COMMITTEE cannot favour one set of cultural values over another but what we can do is support the universal values that make up a decent, just and humane society. We will not play the politicians values game where we somehow favour a set of values held by a small political sub-set. We are concerned with weightier things … with truth, beauty, morality, excellence and equality, and these threads have run through the education that every student here tonight has received. They own these values because they are also the values of their parents, their relatives, their churches, their friends and their employers. They are also the values of each and every one of their teachers. That was in part the address that was given that night in response to the Prime Minister’s arrant nonsense on 20 January 2004. But, when I think about the charge levelled by the Prime Minister and then by the member for Gippsland and his minions, I say to myself, ‘I have had the privilege of being involved in public education for 25 years of my working life.’ Were the institutions that I was involved in, the students, the curriculum and my colleagues valueless? Were we politically correct? Did we not teach what we believed was right and wrong and at least teach people to make their own decisions about what was right and wrong? Were we apathetic to the Australian heritage and values? The answer is no, definitely not. I did a bit of research, as you do on these matters, particularly when you are made anxious by them. Where better to go than to the government, because it preaches values and principles and traditions-on and on? Of course, our current education minister is very good at that. He just parted with $300,000-odd for values and principles and civics in education-good; so be it. There was a values education study published in November 2003. It had a top 10 hit parade of values. Tolerance and understanding, respect, responsibility, social justice, excellence, care, inclusion and trust, honesty, freedom and being ethical were the top 10 values. The night of excellence report by the principal of my local school, it was replete with that. In that school they do not need to read the values education study of November 2003 to find out what these values might be. I looked at the education website in my own state. I said to myself: ‘I have been out of the system for a while. What exactly is underpinning the curriculum? What is underpinning the important social values in our schools today? What does it mean to be publicly educated in Tasmania today?’ WhatI found on their web site is a really interesting program called Essential Learnings which was kicked off in December 2000-not November 2003 but December 2000-by our then state education minister, the Hon. Paula Wriedt. I looked to that to see what the purposes of the essential learnings were and what the values were that underpinned these essential learnings. AndI said to myself, ‘WillI find values there? WillI find principles that I can subscribe to and that I believe reflect the so-called Australian tradition and values?’ So what did I find? It says: We are guided by this core set of values. This core set of values that underline our essential learnings includes: Connectedness, which includes developing a sense of community through friendship, care, compassion, cooperation, acceptance, belonging and sharing. I have ticked it for pretty good values-Aussie values too. Another core value is: Resilience, which includes recognising strengths and maximising potential; developing selfmanagement, self-confidence and self-respect; and nurturing optimism, perseverance and well-being. Tick! Another is: MAIN COMMITTEE Achievement, which includes attaining personal success in a range of human endeavours, pursuing individual excellence and displaying pride and satisfaction in personal achievement. Tick! Another is: Creativity, which includes valuing original ideas, demonstrating enterprise and innovation, and engaging with and responding to the aesthetic qualities of the natural and constructed world. There is no economic bottom line there, but aesthetic values-tick! Another is integrity. Now, what does this mean? ... which includes acting honestly, ethically, and consistently. Tick! Another is: Responsibility, which includes accepting both individual and collective responsibility and contributing to sustainable community development. So values regarding others as well as values regarding the self. And the final value is: Equity, which includes developing tolerance and a commitment to social justiceIs this the problem area?acknowledging diversity, respecting difference and encouraging distinctiveness. Now, that is under threat. It is almost politically correct now not to be tolerant of others. But I gave that a tick, because I think equity is pretty fundamental in our character. So what were the purposes of all these essential learnings? I thought I found some values there, long before the values education study of November 2003. The purposes behind the essential learnings are: Learning to relate, participate and care ... … … … Learning to live full, healthy livesin every sense of the word. They continue: Learning to create purposeful futuresbeing part of the future, not just for yourself but with others and for others. They continue: Learning to act ethicallynot simply knowing what is right and wrong, but being able to justify it and able to justify moral practices. That is a skill. They continue: Learning to learn. That is absolutely essential to being a participating citizen. The final purpose is: Learning to think, know and understand. These are the purposes underpinning the curriculum of essential learnings in Tasmania, based on the values of connectedness, resilience, achievement, creativity, integrity, responsibility and equity. Is this the valueless, politically correct world in public education that the Prime Minister spoke of? Well, if this is valueless, then I am proud to be part of it, and I am proud for both of my sons to have gone through this system of public education. The arrant nonsense that was peddled by the Prime Minister is a disgrace and an embarrassment as is that of all those minions that joined him. We had in the House yesterday from the member for Sturt the feigned indignation which the government are renowned for-the wringing of hands and beating of breasts on anything MAIN COMMITTEE that is pursued by this side. And at this stage, the member for Sturt was attacking the member for Jagajaga. Listen to this hypocrisy! The member for Sturt said: The member for Jagajaga should come into this House and apologise for the fear campaign that she, hand in hand with the AEU, has waged, a campaign that has upset parents and children and created division in the community-and all for what? Grubby short-term political gain. And on it went. Fancy, they: ... upset parents and children and created division in the community-and all for what? Grubby shortterm political gain. The Prime Minister should come into the House and apologise to the people of Australia-to the students, parents, teachers and educators involved in public education and, indeed, in private education-because the implication was that private schools are value-full and public schools are not. He is a disgrace and he should apologise to the people of Australia. bills. But Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 are, I think, the last will and testament of the Howard government. What a dreary little set of documents they are! As I have observed previously while speaking about appropriation legislation, this government takes the prize for the dullest legislation program I think I have ever experienced in my time in this House. Since the government was re-elected in 2001, we have seen a combination of re-runs of legislation that various ministers failed to have passed in previous parliaments and some lacklustre minor legislation that really does not serve to achieve very much. If ever Australia needed a change of government and an injection of vitality and enthusiasm, it is certainly now. I have looked at what has been proposed in these bills to see if there was anything to grab the imagination-anything that would be worth debating and that was not just pandering to the dreariness of the government. Amazingly, I found an issue which did strike a chord with me. It is to do with the Australian Federal Police. The Australian Federal Police, as I am sure most of us are aware, comes under the Attorney-General’s portfolio. It has an important international role. While the $47 million equity projection proposed in Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 is in relation to the deployment of the AFP in Papua New Guinea and operations in the Solomon Islands and people-trafficking issues, there is another role that the AFP is currently performing, and that is on the island of Cyprus. Since 1964 Australia has deployed police to Cyprus as part of a United Nations peacekeeping mission. Originally, it was a joint Commonwealth-state arrangement, but now it is just the AFP. Fifteen AFP personnel are currently in Cyprus contributing to the maintenance of law and order in the buffer zone between the Greek and Turkish Cypriot communities. To give a bit more background: UNFICYP was established in March 1964 to prevent communal violence between the Greek and Turkish Cypriots after there had been a breakdown of law on the island resulting from an attempted coup by members of the national guard and a lot of fighting between the Turkish and Greek communities. The role of the organisation was later expanded to include supervision of a ceasefire between the Turkish army and the Greek Cypriot national guard. UNFICYP also includes a civil police component which is called UNCIVPOL. Australia’s commitment began in 1964 with 40 policemen of the Commonwealth Police. Police from all states were seconded to the Commonwealth Police, which became the Australian Federal Police in 1979 and had its own MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Leo Mcleay (Watson) (4.25 P.m.)
theText: Here we are again, with more appropriationpersonnel. The number of Australian police serving in Cyprus increased to 50 in 1967 before decreasing to 16 in 1975. In May 1988 the first policewoman began service in Cyprus, with many policewomen serving since then. As I mentioned earlier, Australia’s commitment is currently 15 AFP officers serving for a period of six months. Three Australians-Sergeant Ian Donald Ward, Sergeant Lew Thomas and Inspector Paul Hackett-have died on duty with the Australian Federal Police in Cyprus. I am sure that all members will join with me in paying tribute to these officers. There are always risks involved with this type of mission. I believe that Australia’s reputation as a peacekeeper is generally good. While three losses are three too many, I firmly believe that one could realistically have expected there to be a lot more loss of life over the almost 40 years that there has been an Australian police presence on the green line in Cyprus. That it has been contained to three is remarkable in the circumstances. These are dangerous jobs that are fulfilled by our police officers. They are not just overseas jaunts. I have had first-hand knowledge of their work, as I have visited the AFP contingent on the green line in Cyprus up at the airport and along the green line itself on three separate occasions. As I said earlier, their job is not an easy one. There have been persistent rumours in recent times that the government is considering withdrawing Australia’s AFP contingent from the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus. So strong were these rumours last year that the Cypriot community in Sydney, many of whom live in my electorate of Watson, asked me to try and discover if there was any truth behind the rumours. I wrote to the Minister for Justice and Customs in October last year seeking his advice. I pointed out how much our presence in Cyprus since 1964 has been appreciated by the people of Cyprus on both sides of the green line-which it certainly has been. I also pointed out that the overall cost to the Australian economy has been well worth it in terms of the goodwill created and the excellent reputation earned by our national peacekeepers in Cyprus. Furthermore, I told the minister that I share the concern of the Cypriot community about the future of the Australian Federal Police contingent in Cyprus and I sought his advice about the government’s intentions in that regard. For some time in the 1990s I was a member of an IPU committee looking at the Cyprus issue. As indicated earlier in my speech, I visited there a number of times, the two most recent occasions being in September 1996 as a member of a parliamentary delegation with my colleagues the member for Grayndler and the member for Adelaide and also in July 2001. While I was there then, I met the Chief of Mission of United Nations operations in Cyprus, the acting special representative of the Secretary-General, Kofi Annan. So for many years I have taken an active interest in Cyprus and in its future. ThusI was more than happy to take up the concerns of my constituents with the minister last year. The reply that I received from the minister in November 2003 confirmed the view that a review would be taking place but gave no indication of a likely time. However, the minister did say that the review would be of all options concerning the Australian contribution to UNIFCYP as well as East Timor, the Solomon Islands and Papua New Guinea. I do not want to read too much into the fact that additional funding is now being sought in these appropriation bills currently before us for the AFP deployment in Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands, but obviously a decision has been taken to commit additional AFP resources in those two areas. I hope this does not mean a diminution of our commitment in MAIN COMMITTEE Cyprus, particularly at the moment when for the first time after many years it seems there will soon be a resolution of the unsatisfactory situation of the divided island. A breakthrough in the United Nations in New York was reported in the Australian on 17 February this year. The article said that this breakthrough has: ... created a real chance of reuniting the island before it joins the European Union on May 1. For the first time, the two sides in Cyprus, divided since 1974, have agreed to a procedure that cannot collapse or grind to a halt. The article continued: Decisive negotiations begin this week in the capital, Nicosia, on a UN blueprint that would reunite the island in a loose federation of two largely autonomous areas with a central government. A deal would involve territory handovers and large population shifts. As members would be aware, when the island was divided in 1974 the Cypriot community of Greek descent moved to the south of the island and the people of Turkish descent moved to the north of the island into the Turkish zone that was invaded by the Turkish army. The article continued: The breakthrough came when the Greek Cypriot President Tassos Papadopoulos and his Turkish Cypriot counterpart, Rauf Denktash, agreed that UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan can rule on any disputes they cannot settle before a final deal goes to separate referendums in April. Mr Annan said that there was now a real chance that before the first of May Cyprus will be reunited. US mediator Thomas Weston was even more emphatic: “It is almost certain now that there will be a settlement on the island of Cyprus.” I could not be more delighted at this news, and I certainly hope that the reports in the newspapers were not overly optimistic. There has been a long history of disputes on the island. There has been a long history of hopeful breakthroughs that do not result in anything. SoI hope that now people of goodwill on both sides-the Greek and the Turkish Cypriots-will show an equal generosity of spirit in having the matter settled, because the real hope of any solution lies with the people who live there. The ordinary people in Cyprus want a solution. The Turkish government have to come to the party and insist that they want a solution this time. If the Turkish community in the north have their way, they will reunite with their brothers and sisters in the south. We have seen very significant demonstrations in the Turkish ruled zone of Cyprus where Turkish Cypriots have said that they want to reunite the island. We have also seen a lot of Turkish Cypriots voting with their feet by leaving the island. That is not a good thing, and we need a solution. There will be a lot to forgive and a lot to try and forget, but there does need to be reconciliation. While the details might take some time to sort out, it now seems that 30 years after Turkey invaded the northern part of Cyprus there may be a resolution to the situation. It would be a tragedy for Cyprus if, on 1 May when Cyprus becomes part of the EU, only the southern part of the island, which is administered by the government of Cyprus at present, entered the union. The EU have made it quite clear that only the sovereign part of the island, governed by the Cypriot government, will become part of the EU. The people in the north of the island deserve the economic benefits that European Union membership will bring them. They have a lower standard of living than people in the southern part of the island and they have a greater need for the economic benefits which will come from Cyprus being part of the EU. The Greek Cypriot part of Cyprus-the southern part of the island-has very few natural resources. Its only major natural resource is its people and MAIN COMMITTEE their industry and they have shown that, even with the island divided, they have been able to develop a very strong economy in the south built on tourism, banking and services. They are able to hold their heads high, go into the EU and provide the economic stability and advancement that the north of the island requires. It will need a lot of pressure by the Turkish government to get the old Turkish Cypriot regime in northern Cyprus to agree to the amalgamation, but if the people who run the Turkish Cypriot regime in the north of Cyprus genuinely have the ideals and the best interests of the Cypriot people at heart, particularly the Turkish Cypriot people, they will ensure that we achieve a solution to this problem now. It would be absolutely stupid if the Australian government chose this time to withdraw Australia’s AFP contingent or even think of diminishing it. As previous experience has shown in other difficult international situations, once a solution has been found there is still a lot of work to be done to bed down the new arrangements. A harmonious and successful reunification will take time, patience and goodwill on both sides. The Australian AFP, with its well-earned reputation in Cyprus with both sides of the island over the years, will be in an excellent position to assist for however long it takes to bring peace and harmony to the island. While I am pleased to see that AFP personnel are continuing to be deployed overseas and that the government recognises our international responsibility to help preserve stability and security among our near neighbours, I hope that it is not at the expense of our long standing commitment in Cyprus. When the beginnings of a resolution to the problem in Cyprus seem to be so close-the closest it has been in memory-it would be premature of the Australian government to withdraw our police at this sensitive time. As I have said before, it would certainly not be a popular move from the Cypriot community’s point of view, and I know from personal experience that the people of Cyprus appreciate the presence of the AFP. We should hope that the minister will see sense, that the government will ensure that the AFP stay in Cyprus and that the AFP can celebrate the reunification of the island in a way which the Cypriot community here in Australia will be proud of and which the Cyprus government will be appreciative of. The people of Cyprus, who have come to know the Australian police there over that long period, would want them to be there to celebrate the reunification of the island. I hope that the minister will continue to maintain Australia’s presence in Cyprus. In the rest of this appropriation bill, as I said at the beginning, there is very little that the government is proposing that it has not proposed before. There is a lot of dross and very little gold. I was going to speak about some of the decisions that the aviation portfolio have taken, particularly in moving the terminal control units that control along the east cost of Australia to Melbourne, but if I got on to the airport issue I would probably need an extension of time, so I mightloves and enjoys them. He has only an Air Force airport in his electorate, but he might worry a little because, when Brisbane gets bigger, the best place for it to expand will be out to Amberley.
