speaker: Mr Leo Mcleay
theText: My colleague here has heard my airport speeches before, and hecommunity service issues which are very important to many people in my electorate of Oxley and, of course, to a whole range of Australians throughout our country. More specifically I want to outline a number of failures by the Howard government to address these real issues affecting real Australians. I remind people to cast their minds back to 1996 when that famous phrase ‘the Howard battlers’ was coined. Sadly, they have been forgotten by this government. I believe the Howard government has failed to provide adequate assistance for many Australians and their families, and I know that a Latham Labor government would redress these failings as a matter of urgency. Labor has a proven track record, particularly on the issues of health, education and housing, whereas the government has an ever-growing track record of being strong on the weak, weak on the strong, loose with the truth and-their greatest record of all-the highest taxing government in Australian history. In general terms, the Howard government is not committed to delivering real assistance for Australian families. Instead, the government’s approach is to avoid its mutual responsibilities-and we often hear that terminology used in this place by the government. It is a term that in fact does not belong to this government. It should be a term of respect-mutual responsibility is about what we can all do for each other for the betterment of this place. But the term has been hijacked by the government, and I am offended by that because it is a term that Labor has used, but used in a responsible manner. That is what mutual responsibility should be about. But the government has taken that and put it in the too-hard basket. It is no more evident than in what has been revealed recently by a leaked 130-page cabinet document which was presented to the federal government nearly 14 months ago. This document, which the government has sat on for far too long, presented a range of work and family policy options open to the government to redress some of its own failings. What did the government do with this document? It shelved it-it put it to one side and into the too-hard basket. When I asked in question time recently why no action was taken when the government was presented with these policy options, in his response the Prime Minister said that there were more pressing issues to deal with than an options paper about families. I cannot think of any more pressing issue or any issue that should be more prioritised than the well-being of families in this country. At the end of the day, no matter what we do as a parliament and no matter what any party does in government, we should first and foremost look after families. If you look after families, you look after all Australians. But the government failed in this area and put it into the too-hard basket. I also want to briefly outline a few key issues that presently face all Australians, particularly families. Many families struggle to balance the pressures of work and family life. There is no question about that-that is a known fact. Life has become more complicated and much more of a struggle. Families today are finding it increasingly difficult to obtain child-care places. With the requirement for people to go out to work for that double income to match the lifestyles that families are seeking and the expectations that families have, there is a need for more child-care places. Many of them particularly struggle to find after-school care places. Young families need assistance when it comes to that new addition to their family. We should be encouraging new families and more children, and we should be doing that through policy. Parental leave is an important issue, particularly for people re-entering the work force. I also want to take note of the structurally flawed family tax benefits scheme. All of these issues are MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 4 2003 2004 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 2 2003 2004

speaker: Mr Ripoll (Oxley) (4.53 P.m.)
theText: TodayI would like to address a number of family andinterlinked-you cannot separate them. You cannot have a government that decides it is going to deal with one of these issues but not all of them. At the end of the day these issues affect everybody-not only the people in my electorate of Oxley, in Ipswich and western Brisbane, but also the millions of families right across Australia. What the government should be doing is presenting the policies by which they seek to address many of these issues and providing real assistance and real solutions. Government do have the power to make a difference-they can effect change. Where there is a will, there is a way. Where there is another incentive and when it is about saving their political hides, the government find no will to take care of family issues and family matters, but they certainly find the will in other areas-and I will come to that in a moment. So the Prime Minister was right about these issues-about how families balance the pressures of work and family life-when he said, some 19 months ago, that they were very important, but unfortunately he has just done nothing about them. In fact, the Prime Minister has called these things ‘barbecue stoppers’. He is right-they are barbecue stoppers, because they are very important issues. We have heard all the talk but we have seen no action. We have had all sizzle but no sausage; we have had all ham but no burger. Interestingly, when it comes to these very important issues about the government saving its own political hide it will sit on a report for a long time, but when it comes to other matters that affect the Prime Minister’s election hopes then we find a different Prime Minister. The Prime Minister and the government can fix the political problem of parliamentary superannuation-they can fix that in 48 hours-but when it comes to helping Australian families then 14 months go by and nothing happens. How does the government justify that? How does the government go out into the community and explain that? I am going to be asking that question in the lead-up to the election on every opportunity. For 30 years, throughout his career, the Prime Minister has come into this place and defended the parliamentary superannuation scheme, but he backflips on that in 48 hours when he knows that his political hide is on the line. That is the type of person I am talking about. People will and do ask questions about that. But when it comes to helping families and there is a report sitting in the party room, it takes 14 months. And if the report is not leaked and not discovered, nothing happens. This is the tragedy; this is the explanation; this is the definition of this government. This is what this government represents, and that makes me sick. It makes me sick to the bone knowing what this government is truly about. It is not about helping people and families; it is about saving its own political hide. I also want to speak about some specifics and highlight just how the government is failing Australian families. I mentioned before half-a-dozen or more of the issues that are prominent in the lives of many Australians. There are some figures and facts that I think are really important to this debate, particularly in relation to the government’s failed family tax benefit scheme. There have been 2.9 million incorrect payments-56 per cent of all payments, worth $2½ billion-made in error to families. The percentage of family payment debts remains extremely high. It is unacceptable. Families have an average debt of around $900. I find this unacceptable. It is totally unacceptable that the government does not act to fix up this problem. It will find ways to fix up its own problems but not the problems of the families that it should be helping. MAIN COMMITTEE It has underpaid families an average of $32.50 a fortnight. It underpays them and then thinks it is okay to say, ‘At the end of the year we’ll give you a top-up.’ Meanwhile families are suffering. That is why we have those large personal debts and credit card debts-because this government forces people into that position by not dealing with their family tax benefits in a proper way. It is a flawed system that this government should address as a matter of urgency but finds not important enough. It can find the time within 48 hours to do the greatest backflip of all time when it comes to superannuation entitlements for parliamentarians-when it affects them personally-but when it comes to families it cannot find the time. I find this very offensive. In relation to the debts it actually gets worse. The total number of family tax benefit overpayments from July 2000 to September 2003-a relatively short period of time-was 1,639,378. That is right-over 1.6 million mistakes. The dollar value of these overpayments in that period was over $1.4 billion. A growing number of families are being underpaid, and I find that totally unacceptable. The total number of family tax benefit underpayments in that same period of time was nearly 1.3 million, with a total value of over $1 billion. And you ask why families are suffering! Why are families hurting? They are hurting because the government is not dealing with their family tax benefits in the proper way. It is a flawed system. It is a system that hurts ordinary families. Some government members might giggle a bit and think that this may only affect a small percentage of unfortunate people who might not have a job. That is not the case. We are talking about ordinary middle-class Australian families in which one parent or both parents work. They are finding the system so complex, so difficult, that they come to my office to seek assistance not with the actual benefits but in comprehending the forms. These are people who are in middle management or management jobs and are very literate. I have looked at the forms and I find them very confusing. I do not know how ordinary people can fill out those forms. We see the result of that complication and bureaucracy in the millions of underpayments. We see the result in the hundreds of thousands of families that miss out on an entitlement-miss out on something they are due. It is not fair and it should be corrected. But, again, the government cannot find the time. It is not on their list of priorities. On their list of priorities are their political hides. That is the one and only issue on their list of priorities. We find that only 44 per cent of payments are correct, so we are talking about nearly 60 per cent that are not correct. Again, this is just not acceptable. The total dollar value of incorrect payments is $2½ billion. The reason why I highlight these figures is to draw some attention to the quantum-the size, to the actual dollar value, of just how bad this is. An on-point example of a real person in my electorate is that of a young woman who came to my office about a system flaw in her payments. She had identified the flaw and notified Centrelink, but the system would not allow the change because it is not built into the computer system. It is not built into the method by which it can be changed. It has to lie therethe documents are not right; this and that are not right. Every electorate office around this country has gone through this. Every Liberal member, every National Party member and every Labor member knows this is right, because we fix the problems. It is the members who end up sitting down, going through the details and fixing the problems in the bureaucracythe bits that the public servants who are looking after Centrelink cannot fix because they do not have the authority to fix them. MAIN COMMITTEE This is part of the problem with the system. The minister wants all power over what goes on in their own system but accepts no responsibility, so people suffer in a flawed system. We did finally fix this woman’s problem. It was a minor problem but it was a policy problem. We fixed it, but she had to put weeks of stress, pain and time into fixing this problem. That is completely inadequate and wrong. This government should go and fix its system first and let people get on with their lives. It should let people go out there and work for a living and look after their families and not have the stress and burden of this government which cannot do its job. It should not let that burden fall on to our electorate offices and on us, as members of parliament, or directly on to the families in our community. I cannot understand how the government continues to allow this to happen year after year and does not prioritise it. I cannot understand why it does not make it a top-level priority in its own party room to say. ‘This is an important issue we need to fix.’ I think that might change. I have got to tell you here and now, Mr Deputy Speaker Lindsay, that this might change. It is going to change because the government is going to start to suffer in the electorates. That is the only thing that this government understands-electoral pain. If they feel enough electoral pain they will react. We saw that this week. They have ignored veterans; they have not come up with the sorts of packages and things that we need to provide to veterans as the proper entitlement that they are due for their service to this country. We saw Minister Vale come into the parliament-I have to say she has very little respect, if any, left from the veteran community-with the gall to come in under false pretences and not offer the sort of benefits these people are entitled to. I was ashamed that day for this government and the way it treats veterans. But what did it do this week? It suddenly realised: ‘Hang on, we’ve got a fair bit of money stashed away for a rainy electoral day: a $7½ billion surplus. We might have to spend some of that on the people we are hurting the most.’ It has twigged to that little problem it has in terms of the veteran community-the veterans just might do something about it if problems are not fixed. I am glad to see now that there is an almost $300 million package that will actually go to veterans. But, mind you, the government, as always, has been dragged kicking and screaming all the way to the table and the options-all the way to the payments. It does not want to do this. The veteran community should make a note of this: ‘The government does not want to give you that $300 million; it is forced to give it to you.’ It has been dragged there kicking and screaming because we, as the opposition, go into the parliament day after day and take the government to task. We want the government to be accountable for every single cent that it puts away like a miser in a little stash fund called an electoral fund-that $7½ billion surplus-so that it can have a get out of jail free card come the election. That is what is happening. This year may or may not be an election year, but you will see the changes. I think the community is smart enough to know that this year that is where that surplus will be spent. There is a lot of work to be done and a lot of things that need to be redressed, and this government has had way too much time to do it and has not acted on any of it. There were also some interesting statistics that came back to us through the Weekend Australian newspaper, acquired through freedom of information requests, which confirmed the damaging 1.3 million mistakes that affected 700,000 Centrelink customers over a four-month period-700,000 Centrelink customers were affected over four months by Centrelink’s mistakes. I want to make it very clear at this stage that I do not blame the workers of Centrelink. I MAIN COMMITTEE do not blame the people that work there at all, because I know the stresses, regulation and bureaucracy they have to deal with and the pressures that come to them directly from the top-from government in Canberra-about the way they have to apply the rules they have been given. It has become such a complex business now, and we see the government making it more and more difficult for public servants to do their job. And then what does the government do? I was absolutely shocked a couple of weeks ago when we had ministers come into this place and say that public servants cannot do the job well enough and we need to outsource and privatise it. Of course they cannot do the job well enough if you do not give them the tools and the resources. You can always make life difficult for someone if you want to and if you do not resource them properly. The government should make the system better. It should fix the flaws in the system and properly resource Centrelink. It should do all these things to make life for families easier. At the end of the day that is the goal. The priority of government should be to make life for families easier to the point where they do not have to worry about their Centrelink payments or that extra layer of bureaucracy, so that they can get on with their lives and their barbecue stoppers, as the Prime Minister is so keen to point out. The Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham, has talked about a ladder of opportunity. He has talked about the first rung on that ladder being opportunity for all our infant children. The Leader of the Opposition knows, like all of us, that our children are precious and the foundations of our future and that their development is not an issue to be avoided. Their development should be right up there-the No. 1 priority. It should be on the government’s list but it is not. As I have explained before, we know why it is not on that list-that list is crowded by one issue only: the government’s re-election. Throughout my electorate and many like it across the country, people are trying very hard to balance the pressures of family life and work and, more specifically, people are struggling to find adequate child-care places. People often tell me they struggle not only to find adequate beforeand after-school child-care places but also funded places so their kids can be looked after properly in a qualified child-care centre. People also tell me that child care is becoming one of those central issues that make it very difficult for them to continue in their employment. I think that is an issue the government should really pay more attention to. It ends up meaning that those families have to put more pressure on their friends, more pressure on their family and more pressure on the community in order to do the government’s job. The community, friends and family end up doing the government’s job, because the government refuses to accept its mutual responsibility to families in Australia. There is a crisis in child care that this government refuses to fix. The issue of affordability is certainly high on that agenda. In the couple of minutes that I have remaining, I want to mention a specific example of the government’s failure-that is, the Job Network system. The Job Network system is now well and truly stuffed. I do not know if I can find any other way to explain it. This system has failed glaringly. It is a revolving door of unemployment for those who remain unemployed. While I acknowledge that unemployment rates are low, not much has changed for those who are in long-term unemployment. This system that the government has put in place seems to me to be nothing more than a system which it took away from public servants-it took away its own responsibility as a government to provide a Commonwealth employment service-and gave it to private enterMAIN COMMITTEE prise. Private enterprise quickly worked out that, to make a profit-something that this government claims to understand very well-they needed customers. Their customers are the unemployed. Of course, as unemployment tends to fall or as there is no renewal of customers, the Job Network agencies fail. And as they fail, the government finds that it has to top them up. What is it doing? It is topping them up to the tune and $670 million per year. It is finding that, if it does not throw in $1 billion extra to keep them afloat, they and the system will collapse and it will be revealed just how flawed this system really is. In the few words that I have put on the record today, I have highlighted just a few of the many problems that families and communities face in Australia today. But I really want to draw people’s attention to the fact that this government does absolutely nothing about it. It does not prioritise. Labor will do that when it is elected. (Time expired) Ms HOARE (Charlton) (5.13 p.m.)-Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 20032004 constitute the additional estimates bills for 2004. They provide additional funding requirements since the 2003-04 budget and include total appropriations for the three bills of $14,307 million. This is a net increase of $957 million from the 2003-04 budget, which is two per cent of total annual appropriations. These bills also include savings due to changes in policy or parameter variations totalling $473.4 million. These are outlined in the finance document statement of savings expected in annual appropriations. The Appropriations Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 deals primarily with measures since the last budget and, in addition to supply, two new clauses have also been added to this bill which will provide a mechanism for the finance minister upon request from portfolio minister to lapse amounts of departmental expense appropriations which are not required. While we have said that we will support these appropriation bills as we have done every year since 1975, we have moved a second reading amendment that the House condemns the government for its budget waste, mismanagement and wrong priorities which have resulted in a costly Medicare safety net that does not protect families from increasing health costs and declining levels of bulk-billing; inadequate funding and higher fees for students seeking access to higher education; a growing number of families who are financially squeezed in trying to balance work and family and half a million Australians who have been waiting for up to five years to get their teeth fixed. We need to restore doctors’ services in the Newcastle and Lake Macquarie area. Labor has a plan to save Medicare with a $1.9 billion package to reverse the collapse in bulk-billing and by lifting the patient rebate for bulk-billing for all Australians, no matter where they live or how much they earn. A Latham Labor government will immediately lift the Medicare patient rebate for all bulk-billed consultations to 95 per cent of the scheduled fee-an average increase of $3.35 per visit. Subsequently, it will lift the Medicare patient rebate for all bulkbilled consultations to 100 per cent of the scheduled fee-an average increase of $5 per visit. Doctors will be offered financial incentives to keep treating their patients, without additional cost, and to extend bulk-billing, especially in places like Lake Macquarie and Newcastle where the collapse in bulk-billing is really hurting families. Lifting the patient rebate and introducing financial incentives for bulk-billing will help to stem the dramatic decline in bulkbilling and act to make more bulk-billing available to more Australian families. MAIN COMMITTEE Labor will encourage doctors to bulk-bill. We will make access to health care much easier for families, particularly those families who are under financial pressure. Labor stands in stark contrast to the government’s proposals to destroy Medicare, to restrict bulk-billing to pensioners and concession card holders, and to see Australian families pay more every time they visit the doctor. Bit by bit, visit by visit, the cost for Australian families under John Howard will go up. Under Labor’s proposals, there are substantial financial incentives for GPs to continue bulk-billing or to improve their bulk-billing performances. We are very confident that our package, when implemented, will firstly stem the serious decline in bulk-billing and then see bulk-billing go back up towards our national objective of an 80 per cent bulk-billing rate. The Prime Minister knows his package will create conditions in which it will be easier for doctors to charge gap payments for patients and increase their fees for patients who are already paying private fees. There is the ability for doctors to claim the Medicare rebate directly and to charge a gap payment, and it is being held out as an incentive only for those doctors who agree to do John Howard’s bidding for pensioners and concession card holders. As the former President of the AMA, Kerryn Phelps, pointed out: What will need to happen is that for doctors to continue to bulk-bill their concession card holders they’re going to have to charge their non concession card holders more ... The government’s package will drive bulk-billing even lower because, while doctors will be given financial incentives to bulk-bill pensioners and concession card holders, they will be given the green light to charge higher fees for everybody else. Australian families who earn more than $32,300 a year are not eligible for a concession card. For them, bulk-billing will effectively end. When they visit their GP, bit by bit, visit by visit, they will be asked to pay more. We all know that being able to see a doctor when somebody in the family is sick can be pretty tough. Finding a doctor who is prepared to bulk-bill is almost impossible these days. Part of my job as a federal member of parliament is to help our community gain better access to services, including doctors and Medicare. Labor is the party that built Medicare. Labor believes in Medicare. Under Labor, Medicare was not in crisis; it worked. In 1996 more than 80 per cent of visits to doctors cost patients nothing because the doctor bulk-billed. John Howard, in contrast, has never believed in Medicare and his policies have put Medicare on the critical list. John Howard’s policies mean that there are now 21 per cent less bulk-billing consultations each year in West Lake Macquarie and South Newcastle than there were in 2000. This means that greater pressure is being placed on John Hunter Hospital, Belmont Hospital and Wyong Hospital emergency rooms. We all know that there are times when a family needs a doctor and that it is now harder to find one. I will relate a personal experience that happened to me during January. We woke up one morning at home and Reg, my husband, found that he could not swallow. We rang his local medical service and they said, ‘No, the doctor is on holidays. We couldn’t get a locum in and won’t be able to see you for about three or four days.’ I rang another medical service in the area, but the doctor had to go on leave as she had been working hard all year. They could not get a locum in to assist the practice, so the practice in the town had to close down over the break. The advice given to us was to wait at the emergency rooms at the John Hunter Hospital. I would like to think that we are a fairly intelligent family, but on this occasion we decided that we would self-medicate. We looked in the herbal books on the bookshelves, looking for MAIN COMMITTEE ways to try to alleviate the symptoms Reg had, without having to wait at the emergency room at the John Hunter Hospital. If we as a family have to make choices like that, I can just imagine what other people in the community do. In relation to shortages of doctors and bulk-billing, in July last year I expressed my disappointment in this place at the sudden closure of the Wyee Medical Practice in my electorate. I was extremely saddened that the last of the bulk-billing surgeries in the Morisset and Wyee area had closed its doors to the public. The doctors at the surgery were well respected and were the last to regularly bulk-bill patients in the Southlakes area. There are few doctors in the Morisset region who will take on new patients because their books are full. Costs of around $35.50 for a pensioner to visit the doctor are causing many people in our community to turn to our public hospitals for medical attention or they just miss out completely. The community of Wyee and Wyee Point have been left without their bulk-billing doctors. This means that many families will just not seek medical attention because the $35 or $44 to visit the doctor is just not there. There is a clear shortage of doctors in the Southlakes area and, with a significant growing population, the pressure placed on our hard working doctors is mounting. People living in the Southlakes area have been disadvantaged by the closure of the Wyee surgery, which will only add pressure to the existing doctors in Morisset, Cooranbong and Bonnells Bay. We need more doctors in our regions; we cannot afford to see them leave. And we need these doctors to bulk-bill us so all families can access medical attention when they need it. We need a solution to the bulk-billing crisis, and only Labor will deliver a better deal on Medicare for families in the Southlakes area. Following the closure of that doctor’s surgery in Wyee towards the end of last year, the Wyee community faced the possible closure of the Wyee pharmacy owing to the loss of the doctor. I am deeply concerned that because we are still yet to secure the services of a new doctor the pharmacy may have to close. I have been working closely with the community, including Ibraham and Lobna Gahzi, the local pharmacists to bring a doctor back to Wyee. Whilst our efforts continue, there is increasing pressure on the pharmacy to close. Much of the pharmacists’ work is generated by dispensing prescriptions and, without a doctor in town, fewer people are using the pharmacy. Ibraham and Lobna have been great supporters of the Wyee community and it is a tragedy that their business has suffered as a result of the closure of the Wyee Medical Practice. I again call on the government to bring about a solution that will encourage a doctor to come to Wyee. We were advised by the minister that Wyee is a location where an overseas trained doctor is able to access a Medicare provider number. This needs to happen soon before another vital service, the local pharmacy, is lost to the community of Wyee. Moving on to dental care, I have received many letters, emails and phone calls on this issue. As I have responded to them, I emphasise that Labor will invest $300 million over four years in a national dental care program to help those half a million Australians currently waiting up to five years to get treatment. Australian dental care will provide well over a million extra dental procedures for Australians-enough to clear the existing backlog and substantially reduce waiting lists. When the Howard government abolished the Commonwealth dental program in 1996, there were 380,000 Australians waiting an average of six months for public dental care. Now there are more than half a million people waiting as long as five years to get their teeth fixed, and many of the people on these lists are elderly. MAIN COMMITTEE Under Labor’s plan, concession card holders, such as pensioners, and health care card holders and their dependants will now get free check-ups when they need them and subsidised dental treatments, restorations and dentures. Labor will also provide dental health assessments and ongoing care for everyone admitted to nursing homes and will help Indigenous communities with special dental problems, including lack of water fluoridation and diabetes. Under Labor, the federal and state governments will join together in a great national effort because we know that affordable dental care is as essential as any other medical treatment. State and territory governments will spend $384 million on dental services this financial year for health care card holders and school children. Labor believes that dental care is a national responsibility and, unlike the Prime Minister who simply tries to fob it off to the states, a Latham Labor government will work with the states to fix the crisis in dental care. Towards the end of last year, we saw a change in leadership of the federal parliamentary Labor Party. Mark Latham was elected leader and the policies that I have outlined in relation to Medicare, bulk-billing and doctor shortages were released prior to that. So we have shown already that we are a party of positive policy announcements, of policy announcements which have been fully costed and which we know will work to address the ongoing crisis in parts of our community in relation to medical care. Throughout January in the lead-up to the Labor Party’s national conference which was held in Sydney at the end of January a lot of the media and political commentators and many of those in the coalition government were saying that the national conference was going to be a test of Mark Latham’s leadership of the Labor Party. I think a lot of those people would have been sitting back and waiting for Mark Latham to fall at the national conference of the Labor Party. But that did not happen. If that was a test of Mark Latham’s leadership of the Labor Party then he well and truly passed it. Following on from that, we had the media commentators as well as the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and leading government ministers and government backbenchers saying: ‘This is a honeymoon for Mark Latham. This is a honeymoon period for the new leader of the Labor Party.’ After three months of that leadership-three months today-that balloon, that honeymoon period, is nowhere near dissipating. I think the government members would be pleased to have a crisis which would maybe put a hole in that balloon. That is not going to happen. If you have seen the energy, the commitment and the dedication from the new Leader of the Opposition, you will know that that is not going to happen. In the last month or so, the government have gone into panic mode and we have seen their knee-jerk reactions. We saw that with the response from the Prime Minister in relation to parliamentarians’ superannuation. We saw it today in response to the veteran community and the policy announcements to try and shore up their support. I remind the government members and the Prime Minister that the community has a long memory and the community will remember the trail of deceit, the trail of non-core promises and they will ask: ‘Where are the weapons of mass destruction and the reasons we went to war?’ They will remember Tampa. They will remember the children overboard. They will remember Peter Hollingworth. They will remember the never, ever GST. They will remember the no $100,000 university fees. They will remember the reason we went to war was because of the so-called weapons of mass destruction, but now the Prime Minister tells us it was good to get the regime change. The MAIN COMMITTEE electorate will remember these things. No amount of back-pedalling or spending the budget surplus is going to make them feel any other way. The opposition’s amendment to this legislation also goes to the issue of government waste. It was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald by Alan Ramsey on 18 February following budget estimates in which our two experts-Labor Party Senators John Faulkner and Robert Ray-raised some questions about expenditure on the Lodge. The total expenditure came in at about $140,000 which included 10 armchairs at $23,000-odd, carpeting, painting and new timberwork, design fees, timber removal, curtains, two bathrooms and lighting. The article reports Senator Faulkner saying: Is that the full horror? And the official replied: There is still some carpeting. They then moved on to the ‘retirement lifestyle’ of Peter Hollingworth. You would remember that Peter Hollingworth was, as Ramsey reports: …[the] former archbishop and tainted governor-general who resigned, under pressure, a year ago after just 23 turbulent months and walked away with an annual pension of $184,000, a car and driver and first-class air travel for life, and an office and secretarythank you very much! Senator Ray, in budget estimates, as Ramsey reports: … wanted to know about Hollingworth’s 21st-floor office in Melbourne that taxpayers maintain. How big was it? Official: “145 square metres for him and his staff.” How many staff? “One.” Faulkner: “145 square metres for two people? That is bigger than a lot of houses in this country, isn’t it?” Official: “I do not know.” Faulkner: “Well, I do.” And we all do, too. Ramsey’s article said Senator Ray then asked: “Were any renovations required?” Official: “There was a fit-out, yes.” Ray: “How much?” Official: “The total cost?” Ray: “Yes.” The official said that the total cost of the fit out of this 21st floor office of 145 square metres for two people was $234,000. Those are just a couple of examples of government wastage in this area. I referred to the national conference and the various policy announcements which were made there. We also announced the policy of Read Aloud Australia, where parents are supported in reading aloud to their children from day one-because we know that learning begins at day one-and the BookStart program, where every new parent will be offered three new books to read to their children. We also had the announcement that Lindsay Tanner, the member for Melbourne, had been appointed the shadow minister for community relationships. We all know that people out there in the community do not sit around the pub talking about the state of the economy; they sit around the pub talking about the state of their families, the state of their community, their community security, how their kids are going and what is happening in their everyday lives. SoI applaud the Leader of the Opposition for making those announcements at our national conference. They were great announcements and there are many more where they came from. In conclusion, and because I have referred to the new Leader of the Opposition, I would just like to take this opportunity to salute Simon Crean, the member for Hotham. Simon always had my support. Simon is a good man; he was a good leader. Unfortunately, events conMAIN COMMITTEE spired against him. I wish him and Carole all the best, all the time. I consider them good friends. We did a lot under the leadership of Simon Crean and I applaud him for that. Weekend Australian Magazine of 21 and 22 February a reference-to a part of my electorate-which I consider to be full of judgment and prejudice. A number of people in this chamber might have read the article that I am talking about. It was an otherwise excellent piece of writing by a journalist named Stuart Rintoul. It was an article about a very well-known and prominent defence barrister named Colin Lovitt. I thought it was a good piece of writing about Colin Lovitt and it was interesting reading, but I must take issue with a reference that Stuart Rintoul made in his article to what he described as the ‘rural slum of Moe’. I am very proud to represent the town of Moe in my electoral district. It is a beautiful town and an absolutely fantastic place to live. It is surrounded by rolling hills to the south and an absolutely gorgeous mountain range to the north. It is a large and vibrant township of about 18,000 people, and it has a magnificent sense of community. I have been proud to have the support of so many people in Moe in my political life for quite a few years, and very proud to count so many people in Moe as my trusted and closest friends. I want to say this in the parliament: I think Stuart Rintoul did the wrong thing by making that reference to Moe. It is an uninformed comment and a comment that is full of prejudice and judgment. I say to Stuart Rintoul through this parliament that we really count on people like him in the media to be responsible in the comments they make about towns and districts, because what they say has a big effect on how people perceive the towns, districts and regions in which we live. I think it would be appropriate for Stuart Rintoul and the Weekend Australian to apologise to the people of Moe for that reference. It might have been an inadvertent reference, but the damage has still been done. People in Moe are hurt by that reference. It is a reference which is unfair. It is a comment on the people of Moe which is not deserved. We all know that when you refer to a slum in an Australian context the general usage of that word is associated with a place like Calcutta where there is desperate poverty and there are awful physical circumstances and people living in horrendous personal situations. We all know that that is what the word ‘slum’ refers to. We know that that reference is unsuitable when talking about a beautiful town and a vibrant community full of good people, all working hard to get ahead, which is what we have in the township of Moe. I want to use the time that I have available today to draw attention to the response that we have had from the public schools right across my electorate to the awful comments made by the Prime Minister in relation to the public school system. It might be worthwhile my reminding the House exactly what those comments were. The Prime Minister said: ... theytalking about the parentsfeel that government schools have become too politically correct and too values-neutral. And the acting education minister, Peter McGauran, said: ... there is a worrying trend within state schools, that there is a jettison of traditional values and heritage of Australia. He went on to say: MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 4 2003 2004 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 2 2003 2004

speaker: Mr Zahra (Mcmillan) (5.33 P.m.)
theText: I was appalled and disgusted when I saw in the... there is a growing trend that is discernable to parents that too many government schools are either value free or are hostile to, apathetic to, Australia’s heritage and values ... Those comments are appalling and very uninformed. They are an insult to all those hard working teachers and support staff who commit themselves so fully and energetically to providing quality education to our students in public schools. Quite a response has been created in my electorate not only from people in the public school system but also from people in the Catholic and independent school systems who were appalled at the Prime Minister’s comments and who think that these types of generalisations and stereotypes of schools or teachers are highly inappropriate. I have some letters here from schools across my electorate in response to what the Prime Minister has said. I want to read part of what they have said in their letters to me into the Hansard for the record. One letter is from a rural primary school in the beautiful Latrobe Valley. It says: Christian, you must have noticed even in your visits to our school how seriously we emphasise the values of respect and civility to visitors. This is even more so when we are out of the school. The students know very clearly what is expected. The principal goes on to say: This year at our school, we are launching the You Can Do It program. This actually teaches the indicators research has shown make a successful student and citizen. These indicators are: organisation, academic confidence, persistence and getting along with others. Underpinning these success indicators are a whole range of values: respect for others, respect for property, independence, giving of your best, expectations that tasks will be completed, putting in an effort, planning time, listening to others, tolerance, playing by the rules, thinking first-the list goes on. These aspects of successful citizenship are actually taught. There are specific lessons on these values. The principal concludes by saying: Christian, can you imagine what schools would be like if tolerance, respect and a conscientious approach to study were not inherent in the values of a school? It would be chaos, and my school is not that. I have been to that principal’s school on several occasions, and I can guarantee that his school, like so many other public schools in my electoral district, is an excellent school. It provides a fantastic education to all of its students. Another letter I have received in relation to this issue is from the principal of one of the large state primary schools in the west Gippsland area. He has written a letter to the Prime Minister which he has copied to me. As principal of his school, he writes to the Prime Minister: I am deeply offended by your comments regarding state government schools and their values. As the elected political leader of this country your effort should be constructive and inclusive, not divisive and politically point scoring. He goes on to say: ... it is a large primary school with a strong culture of producing high-quality, well educated students. We operate in a very competitive environment. The whole community sees our school as offering outstanding quality education. The values and heritage enunciated at this school truly reflect the parent community and are clearly stated. Your recent statements not only damage years of hard work and effort but also the image of my staff and their profession. MAIN COMMITTEE This was typical of the response I had from schools right across my electorate in relation to the Prime Minister’s comments about public education. I would like to read from another letter I have got, which is from a large public primary school in one of the towns in the Latrobe Valley. The principal wrote to me and said: Like you, I was appalled at the indiscriminate demeaning of schools. He goes on to say: It is unfortunate that the Prime Minister’s comments and those of many of his colleagues have in one broad, generalised sweep undermined the work and integrity of teachers and parents who are contributing so much to the growth and development of this nation. I am personally embarrassed because it has taken the focus away from the real issues facing schools today. I support that view and I think he has hit the nail on the head. The real issue facing the federal parliament in relation to schools is not some type of false debate that the Prime Minister might want to try and start which relates to his idea of values; it is about where the funding goes that the Commonwealth provides to schools. We have a situation now where the more money schools have the more money they get, which means that poorer districts-mostly in rural areas-miss out. All of the big increases go to the King’s School, Geelong Grammar, Wesley College and Trinity College-schools that charge $15,000 or $16,000 per year for just one student to study. Not one single person in my electorate can afford that. The real debate, which was alluded to in that letter I just read out, is about why it is that the Howard government sees fit to give those schools the most money and not adequately fund the public school system and low-fee Catholic and independent schools and recognise the needs of their students and the communities they serve. I had many other responses, from principals, school councils and students right across my electorate. I want to read out a response from a principal who leads one of the public secondary colleges in the south Gippsland region. He says that at his school: Our core values and expectations are: valuing people, valuing diversity, mutual respect, honesty, trust, resolving conflict positively, recognising and encouraging people’s strengths, respecting individuality, fostering a sense of community where we care about everyone. People are encouraged to make positive choices, taking responsibility for actions and achievements. His letter goes on: We teach these core values and expectations in the curriculum, with a subject known as people skills. This has commenced this year at years 7, 8 and 9. We are a project school for social competencies, which we have called people skills. He includes some three pages in his letter that set out in more detail all of the values and skills which his school is teaching its students as it prepares those young people for life. There are so many other responses that I have received, from some excellent schools right across my electoral district. I hope that the Prime Minister is listening to my contribution today and hearing first-hand what educators, people who are in the field servicing communities in country areas, actually think of the comments that he made about their schools and the school system, which he has, in one broad statement, demeaned in such a disgraceful way. I had the good fortune the other day to get a briefing from the Trafalgar district community association. The Trafalgar district community association are good people who have been working very hard on behalf of the residents and the citizens of Trafalgar and have really been a very powerful force within that community in setting a positive agenda for the town and MAIN COMMITTEE making sure that things happen when they are planned. I received a briefing from the Trafalgar district community association, from the people from the youth resource centre in the town, from the Trafalgar Chamber of Commerce and from a number of people who are involved directly with the Trafalgar district community association in terms of organising the strategic direction for the town. The group have steered the development of the Trafalgar strategic plan and its sister publication, the Trafalgar action plan. They are two excellent publications, which are the result of extensive work and public consultation that has been done by the people involved in the Trafalgar Community Development Association. I just want to use this public opportunity in the parliament to congratulate the people involved in the Trafalgar Community Development Association for the work which they have done. In particular, I want to congratulate Mick Bourke, who has been their president for quite some time, for the work which he has done and the leadership he has provided to that organisation. It is a wonderful town, Trafalgar, and I am absolutely convinced that it has a very positive future. It will continue to have a positive future so long as there are people in the community like Mick Bourke and all the other people involved in the Trafalgar Community Development Association who give so willingly of their time and effort and creativity to ensure that a future for Trafalgar is not something that people take for granted but something that people work towards and plan towards. Well done to Mick and his team and to all of the people who are involved in the Trafalgar Community Development Association. I had the opportunity last week to meet with the people involved with the Coal Creek Heritage Village, which is one of Victoria’s premier tourist attractions and is located in the southern part of my electorate, in Korumburra. It is an excellent place. I have been there several times and I am sure many other people in the House have been there before as well. You will be pleased to know, Mr Deputy Speaker Wilkie, that it is celebrating its 30th birthday this month. The story of Coal Creek is quite amazing and an excellent example of the determination, resourcefulness and cooperation of rural Australian communities. Coal Creek was planned, developed and built by the Korumburra community. The village has benefited from ongoing financial assistance initially from the old Korumburra Shire Council and, more recently, from the South Gippsland Shire Council. However, the vast majority of the original construction was undertaken by volunteer labour, and most of the relics, artefacts and antiques that make up the collection were donated by local residents and families. The day-to-day operation of the village has across its 30-year history relied heavily on volunteers in staffing roles as tour guides and in maintaining the village. Korumburra is a relatively small town, as you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, yet the local community supplies around 30 volunteers per week to keep Coal Creek functioning. It really is a great achievement that the people of Korumburra have been able to keep Coal Creek functioning for so long and have made it such a success. TodayI want to briefly give some special recognition to a number of volunteers. One standout volunteer amongst a bigger group is Anne Hopwood, who recently retired as a volunteer at Coal Creek after 25 years of continuous services. Anne and her husband run a dairy farm in the Korumburra area and have raised a family of three children. However, she still found time to donate at least a day’s voluntary labour to Coal Creek almost every week across the past 25 years. Keith Dunstan is a relative newcomer compared to Anne. He first became MAIN COMMITTEE involved with Coal Creek around 15 years ago. Since then, he has adopted the village. He is often there seven days per week, feeding the farm animals and tackling all manner of maintenance projects. Keith is also an active member of many of the groups and subcommittees that form the basis of operation and support at Coal Creek. When Coal Creek was first suggested, Hugh Henry was a local councillor. He was a member of the original investigative committee and a prime mover in developing and progressing the project. He then took on the role of manager of the village, once it opened, and remained in that position for its first 15 years of operation. Since then, he has been a regular visitor, returning to offer his services across a broad range of areas, including building maintenance and general repairs. Hugh has a wealth of knowledge on the history and original development plans, and he remains only too happy to share that with the current management. There are many other examples of local people who have given so much to the Coal Creek Heritage Village over its 30 years of operation. Well done to Ken Joiner, the current manager of the Coal Creek Heritage Village, in making sure that we properly celebrate this 30th anniversary. I would like to place on record the great regard that I have for the many volunteers who have worked so hard over so many years to make sure that Coal Creek is the excellent tourist facility that it is and that the important history of coal mining in and around the south Gippsland district is preserved for future generations. 2003-2004 and cognate bills, I want to raise some particular issues with respect to two reports of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services, of which I am a member. One report is entitled Money matters in the bush and the other report is entitled ATM fee structure. These two related reports went into a range of issues regarding access to, and availability and serviceability of, banking services in rural and regional Australia in particular-although the report on the ATM fee structure had a slightly wider remit with respect to that issue. The reports, on balance, are broadly endorsed by all members of the committee. However, Labor members disagreed with coalition members on a number of issues, and I would like to focus on those particular areas and recommendations. In the first report-Money matters in the bush-there was some difference of opinion on a number of recommendations. These recommendations covered issues such as notifications for closure of banks, older person and disability access, accounts, balances provided at EFTPOS, Indigenous communities and banking, and community obligations. I will just go through some of those recommendations and highlight some of the differences of opinion in order to make the Main Committee more aware of the concerns that were held. Recommendation 3 in that report related to the question of improved consultation and, in particular, a notice period of some six months to be provided if a branch was the only branch in a town that was left and that branch was to close. Labor certainly support that recommendation. It is actually in line with what our policy has generally been with respect to the issue of branch closures. Our belief, though, is that you should not just look at it from a rural and regional point of view in that respect. It is a very significant issue in those areas, but there are also metropolitan suburbs and communities where branch closures and their circumstances are also quite traumatic for local businesses and communities. Therefore, although we MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 4 2003 2004 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 2 2003 2004

speaker: Mr Griffin (Bruce) (5.53 P.m.)
theText: In rising today to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3)fully support this recommendation for rural and remote areas, we also believe it ought to be the case for the community in general and should cover branch closures, full stop. Recommendation 4 related to the question of the gathering of data by APRA and concerns about the question of how that was operating. I am going to quote extensively from the committee report in various ways, shapes and forms but, in respect to that matter, Labor members shared the community’s concern that there does need to be improved analysis and commentary on the information provided through the points of presence database. While the committee has requested that another government agency and not APRA be requested to do this, Labor members believe that APRA should have a role in analysing and commenting on the data but that this should be done by APRA in conjunction with the ACCC. Given the ACCC’s role in assessing levels of competition in the banking services industry, they would bring a good deal of expertise to any assessment of access to banking services. We think that more can and should be done there. Recommendation 12 relates to the question of older Australians. Labor supports the priority placed on introducing industry standards to support older Australians and those with disabilities to achieve full and equal access to services such as ATMs and EFTPOS. With respect to recommendation 22 on the issue of expansion of displays of account balances, Labor supports the expansion of EFTPOS facilities to allow for access to account balances. However, there should not be an additional fee for this service and the balance information request should not be considered as a transaction where consumers can only access a limited number of fee-free transactions. It gets back to the issue that we are now at a stage with banking services where, even if you blink at your ATM, you need to respond by paying some sort of fee. The nature of fee payments with respect to this industry has just grown like Topsy over the last few years. It is something that the banks have seen as an ever-growing area for increasing their revenue streams. It is certainly the way that they have been dealing with the benefits of competition that occurred around the Labor government’s reforms in that area regarding things like mortgage providers and interest rates. Another area where concerns were held related to some of the recommendations not going far enough, particularly with respect to the issue of Indigenous communities. Much evidence was taken by the committee on the difficulties confronting Indigenous Australians regarding access to banking services and financial literacy generally. It is apparent that many remote and regional Indigenous communities lack sufficient basic banking services. In some cases it is not an issue of services previously enjoyed being withdrawn but, rather, of services never having been provided at all. As important, the lack of such services is compounded by factors such as remoteness; socioeconomic disadvantage, which in some instances is extreme; poor levels of numeracy and literacy; and, accordingly, low levels of financial literacy, cultural difference and language barriers. Labor members consider that access to basic banking services and minimum levels of financial literacy are preconditions to addressing the disadvantage experienced by many Indigenous communities in remote and regional Australia. There is little point in governments encouraging Indigenous Australians to achieve greater economic independence if the basic building blocks of economic development are not in place. Accordingly, while Labor members were generally supportive of the committee’s recommendations with regard to Indigenous Australians, we also made the following additional MAIN COMMITTEE points. In relation to recommendations 24 and 26, Labor members see a need for a multifaceted strategy to improve the financial literacy of Indigenous Australians which is coordinated by the government and which involves Indigenous organisations, state and territory governments and financial institutions. Whilst we support recommendation 24, which calls for financial literacy to be included in core school curricula, we consider this to be only one of a number of strategies that are required. We also believe the involvement of Indigenous organisations, particularly those with demonstrated success in the area of financial literacy education, to be critical. Further, we consider that recommendation 26 fails to go far enough. It is insufficient to call on the ABA to simply examine the successful practices utilised in Canada in relation to Indigenous financial literacy. In our view, the ABA should develop, in partnership with relevant Indigenous organisations, a comprehensive strategy for improving the financial literacy of Indigenous users of banking services, drawing on the Canadian experience. Labor members are encouraged by some of the initiatives taken by some banks and also by the ABA’s indicated willingness to work with Reconciliation Australia on this issue. However, it is our view that, in the event these voluntary initiatives prove to be insufficient, these issues would properly be considered in the context of compulsory community service obligations. Recommendation 29 related to the issue of the Banking and Financial Services Ombudsman. In particular, Labor members believe that the jurisdiction of the BFSO should be widened further to encompass consumer complaints about the cost of banking services. This is part of that wider discussion. I think the Banking and Financial Services Ombudsman does a pretty good job in many respects; however, the fact of the matter is that he is dramatically limited by the extent of his charter. There are a range of issues which get raised with the BFSO on a regular basis that are not able to be investigated. Those are genuine complaints about the operation of the banking sector but they are complaints which the BFSO is unable to deal with. That is a fault in the system. It means that a range of issues that ought to be investigated are not able to be investigated by an appropriate body such as the BFSO. That is something that I think is incredibly unfortunate. In this particular case, the committee may not have realised the extent of the need but certainly the Labor members do realise that those issues need to be looked at. Going on from that, there is recommendation 30, which from Labor’s point of view related to the issue of supporting the introduction of community service obligations on ADIs. It is a point that we have made repeatedly in the past. We have said that once again we are prepared to look at reregulating the banks if they do not agree to meet appropriate voluntary community service obligations. Our view is that, until we get the banks to the table in a situation where they understand that the regulators and the government of the day are serious, we will not be able to get real movement on a range of issues. The experience with the sector in the past has been that, when they think things are about to happen, you tend to find that they are then prepared to look at what they might do. We believe more can be done in that area. We stress that as something that should be done in the future. I will go on now to the issue of ATM foreign fee structures, which was the subject of a follow-up report that effectively came out of the main report that I have just spoken about. ATMs are a very important part of what is now the banking sector in this country. Many of us hereand no doubt Deputy Speaker Causley would be amongst us-certainly found that initial peMAIN COMMITTEE riod of moving across to using an ATM to be of some difficulty. I know that I did. I do not think that is something to be worried about. In my early years it was a matter of going into a bank branch rather than dealing with the infamous hole in the wall. However, most of us have conquered this to a large degree in the last 20 years or so and now it is something that we have taken for granted as being a bread-and-butter part of the banking sector. However, there are many things that a hole in the wall cannot do. The experience right across Australia, particularly in rural and regional areas, is that bank branches are the sorts of services that go. We lose the bricks and mortar and the services which relate to that. We are seeing in a range of ways more innovative solutions now being used to deal with some of these issues. That is a good thing, but the bottom line-and this is something that the committee found in its inspections-is that there is still a general and genuine view pervading the community in many rural and regional areas that, although in many respects the new services were good and occasionally in some respects they were better, overall service delivery had dropped and that that was detrimental to the operation of the local community. When you take away those banking services, you end up in a situation where they are simply the first things to go. Then the stores start to leave. The next thing you know-and we saw them-some towns effectively almost turn into ghost towns, not quite overnight but certainly in the passing of merely several years. With ATMs the question is: what is happening with respect to the fee structures in those areas? A review is going on at the moment, looking at the question of ATM fees, and there is a working party of the industry, which has come forth with some recommendations about how to deal with those fees. In a nutshell, it involves the abolition of certain fees and a recommendation for more transparency in charges so that when you look at an ATM you would be able to see what you would be charged for undertaking a particular transaction. In the scope of that, there would effectively be a deregulation of what we call foreign ATM fees-that is, when you use an ATM of another institution. In my case, as a Commonwealth Bank customer, if I were using a Westpac, an ANZ Bank or a National Australia Bank ATM, it would be a question of what fee would be charged in those circumstances. By deregulating this area, the concern is that we would potentially find absolutely exorbitant fees being charged, particularly in rural and regional areas but also in some metropolitan areas, depending on the particular circumstances. The situation with respect to rural and regional Australia is that it is potentially very damaging. Certainly some of the evidence that was taken at the hearing into this matter highlighted that. The representative from the Country Women’s Association, Chris Connolly from the University of New South Wales and representatives from the Australian Consumers Association stressed the fact that many things could happen in this area and that the international experience suggested very clearly that rural and regional communities should be very concerned about what might happen. We are talking about a situation where, over the last decade or so, some 750 branches have closed, and those communities have been put into a situation where they need to use electronic banking. Forty per cent of Australian transactions were at foreign ATMs, and this proportion is likely to be higher in the bush where there is often only one bank in a town and therefore not the same level of choice that you would have in metropolitan areas. In my case MAIN COMMITTEE now, because of these sorts of fees, I look for Commonwealth Bank ATMs rather than using another institution’s ATM, because I know that I will be dealing with some additional cost. a new experienceyou can teach an old dog new tricks in some cases-but not always. The transaction rate even now, with respect to these fees, can range between $1.35 and $2. When you look at the movement in these foreign ATM fees as they currently stand, before we go to deregulation, you see that they have increased by something like 250 per cent since 1995. What we are saying is that there are several bottom lines which ought to be the basis of the implementation of these reforms and which we worry about, given the report as it currently stands and where the working party is up to with respect to recommendations. Firstly, we believe that any change should reduce the overall cost of banking to customers. This should be a logical conclusion of these changes, because the fact is that, when you do an examination of the actual cost to the institution for undertaking this service compared to the fees that are charged for electronic transactions, those fees are almost invariably at a significantly higher level of profit than is reasonable for the provision of the service. There should be-and, in our view, there must be-a reduction in the overall cost of banking to customers in this area. We also need to ensure that customers in regional areas are not slugged with higher fees than those charged in the major cities. I will come back to that in a minute. We need to prevent institutions with large ATM networks from using their market power to impose higher charges on customers of smaller institutions. One of the recommendations in the report which Labor has strong concerns about is recommendation 1. I will read out that recommendation. It mentions the creation of ‘safeguards that would ensure that people living in country towns and remote communities do not incur significantly higher fees or charges for using a foreign ATM and that an unreasonable or unwarranted differential in fees and charges between those in rural and remote areas and those in metropolitan areas does not develop’. The key point there is ‘an unreasonable or unwarranted differential in fees and charges’. Although the majority of the committee said that we should not be in a situation where there is an increase in charges for certain areas, that is actually conceding that there is scope for-and, in fact, it is effectively endorsing-differential fee charging. While it is saying that it should not be unreasonable or unwarranted, it is still saying there is not a problem with it actually occurring. The member for Wannon is present today and I am sure he would be concerned about what the results might be there. Going by this recommendation, the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services has basically said that it is okay to have a differential rate for foreign ATM transactions between the city and the country. That is what it has basically said. It has said that the differential should not be unreasonable or unwarranted, but it is still saying it can be there. The fact of the matter-and the member for Wannon has some expertise in these matters, given that he is the chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration-is that, over time, we have MAIN COMMITTEE

theText: and out of character, as he says, but there you go. It just goes to show thatseen a lot of evidence on the way that banking institutions have operated with respect to the provision of services. I think that, if we asked many members of the public and certainly many members of parliament who deal with regional and rural areas in particular whether the actions of the banks with respect to branch closures over the years have been reasonable or warranted, we would find that, in many cases, there would be significant concerns. The fact is that being reasonable and not introducing unwarranted changes is not something that we have come to expect from banking in this country. We can be sure that, with this sort of change, when you open the door they will use every capacity to try to make sure they keep that door open and use it to great effect. That has been the experience in this area where you have had changes and scope for fee increases. Look at the increase we have seen in fees just in this case under the current system-some 250 per cent since 1995, just with this type of fee. When you look at the situation with fees overall, right across the board with banking, you know that they have a very different view of what is unreasonable or unwarranted. I am not convinced by the guarantees from the banks. I am not convinced from the wording of that particular recommendation from the committee that what we are going to see is a situation where rural and regional communities get a fair go. I think we are in real danger now of seeing a divide developing-a divide that will mean that it is more expensive than it should be for people in those sorts of communities. I want to make it very clear: the Labor Party will not stand by and let this occur. Other parties have to look at their positions on this, but they can be very clear that we will not stand by and let this happen. (Time expired) Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, I indicate my support for the second reading amendment moved by our spokesperson which talks about the government and its budget, the waste and mismanagement of the budget and the wrong priorities that have resulted in a Medicare safety net that does not protect families from increasing health costs and declining levels of bulk-billing. I have had the opportunity to talk about this phenomenon in my local area, where we see a decline in the levels of bulk-billing and an increase in the number of people who are attending the accident and emergency centre of the Northern Hospital. Something in excess of 60 per cent of attendances there are categories 4 and 5, which could be dealt with by general practitioners if they were available. Part of the reason that people attend the hospital is the lack of after-hours services by GPs, the low level of GPs in the outer suburban area that I represent and the fact that there is a decline in the levels of bulk-billing. The second point in the second reading amendment was on inadequate funding and higher fees for students seeking access to higher education. This debate occurs at a time when one of the local universities servicing the northern suburbs of Melbourne, La Trobe University, has indicated that it will increase its HECS fees by 25 per cent. This is making it harder for people, at a crucial time in their lives, to make the decision to go forward and take the opportunity that tertiary education gives them. It is no use saying that because of the way the HECS system works they are able to defer the payment. These people know that at the end of their course they are going to have an increased level of indebtedness that they are going to have to work off during their lifetime, which is an impediment to their decision to go forward to tertiary education. The third item is the growing number of families who are financially squeezed in trying to balance work and family. In the outer suburbs of Melbourne this is clearly identified by the MAIN COMMITTEE
