speaker: Mr Jenkins (Scullin) (6.13 P.m.)
theText: In rising to speak in this debate on Appropriationway in which people are feeling the squeeze of trying to establish their family home, juggle their responsibilities with family and, at the same time, stay in employment-often where they have to travel long distances, because a lack of local infrastructure to support them is getting to a crucial stage. The last item in the second reading amendment is the 500,000 Australians waiting up to five years to get their teeth fixed. I have had the opportunity to talk about the need for the Commonwealth’s involvement in a dental health scheme on a number of occasions. As each day goes by it is clear that there could be great advantage brought about if the Commonwealth were to decide to enter into a partnership with the state and territory governments and community organisations that are working in this field to ensure that we can get back to a negligible waiting list, as we saw when the Commonwealth Dental Health Scheme was in existence. Today, I want to use the opportunity provided by this wide-ranging debate on these appropriation bills to talk about the way we discuss public issues in the Australian parliament. I want to illustrate this by using four examples of current issues being discussed to indicate not only the ways in which the parliament could display its strengths but also the weaknesses in the way we deal with things. I want to try to suggest ways we can improve parliamentary discussion of important issues. The first item I want to mention is the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD: Intelligence on Iraq’s weapons of mass destruction. As an aside, I am pleased that the committee’s secretary is in the chamber at the moment and I congratulate her on her involvement in this report. This is an important example of the way in which this parliament can work at its finest. Subsequent to the report being released, I am yet to be convinced that it is being handled in a proper way. I was a little disappointed that only half an hour was available for discussion of this during Monday’s private members’ business. That is no reflection on those who allocate the time, but it illustrates my point. Especially in this case, when there are four members of the House of Representatives who are members of the committee, they should have been given a longer time than five or ten minutes to talk about it in the chamber. I hope that we get an opportunity as a parliament to discuss the contents of the report, because the items that this report covers are very important. They are not only important for the historical basis of the government’s decision to involve Australian troops in Iraq but also, as I have had the opportunity to say before, as an example of public policy decision making and the way in which a government portrays the information it has and uses as the basis for a decision, which then leads-if it is not done carefully-to a distrust of the way in which those decisions are made. It is really about the political scenario that the government used to, in a way, pick the items which were available to it that it wished to latch onto. The other elements go to more rigorous investigation and examination of the information available. But most importantly it goes to the way in which that information was used in justifying to the community decisions that the government made. If on this occasion, as I believe, this information was used to the extent that decisions were brought forward long before they really had to be made, there is a large part of the public that then, on that basis, asks, ‘Why would we in future believe any of the decisions that a government makes to commit troops overseas?’ I hope that as a parliament we get an opportunity to more fully discuss this report. The second item I wish to reflect upon is the US free trade agreement. It will not surprise members that I approach this with a great deal of caution, right down to the fact that I would MAIN COMMITTEE be much happier if we were actually talking about a fair trade agreement with the United States. That perhaps gives a hint about the angle that I come from. That is perhaps not the majority view of the Australian parliament. I am not sure that it is the majority view of the Australian Labor Party. But I will simply keep up the fight. I think it is an angle from which we have to approach these problems and from which we can improve our best interest in dealing with our trading partners and opponents. My beef about the United States free trade agreement is that, in the two to three weeks since the late Australian time that this was settled upon, (a) we have not seen the detail of the document and (b) there has not been a proper discussion by the parliament about the free trade agreement. Critics will say that I am being unfair because when this appears magically after being legally scrubbed-or whatever the technical terms are for the state that it is in at the moment-it will be going to the committee systems of the parliament, and that should suffice. But I believe this is a situation in which there should have been a ministerial statement and in which there should have been a debate. Since this agreement has been cobbled together into its final state there have been 17 questions without notice, including three today from the opposition. But before today there were 14, four of which came from the opposition and 10 from government members. At the end of the day, those 10 are dorothy dixers. Within the limitations of the standing orders-and again I do not wish to reflect upon decisions made by people about the legitimacy of questions under the standing orders-they are used to elicit an angle, to allow the Minister for Trade to get up and give the government’s spin and angle. Instead of that government spin and angle about this free trade agreement there should have been an announcement by way of a ministerial statement in the parliament about the government’s view on the agreement. That would have led to a response by the opposition and perhaps somewhere down the track a fuller discussion by members of both houses about the intent of the agreement. I am surprised that this has not occurred if we are to believe the government when they say that this is an important agreement. If it is so important, it should have been subject to a discussion and a debate. As I have said, the fact that these matters are not sufficiently discussed is a flaw in the way in which we deal with them. This is something that perhaps should have had fuller discussion during the negotiations. There were a lot of views about. I do not think it is an unhealthy prospect that in a parliamentary democracy like ours there should be a divergence of views. I note that the government seems to want to fit the opposition in its view about the free trade agreement by indicating that it is motivated by pure anti-Americanism and things like that. It has been clear from the outset that the Leader of the Opposition has said that he wants to look at this agreement with Australia’s best interests in view. It is pretty hard to do that when you do not have the detail of the agreement. Having said that, I think we have been fairly consistent in the view that we have about this agreement-that it should be viewed in that way. One of the shortcomings-because of the things that have been in and out, the things that are at the edges and the timetables that are used in some sectors-is whether it is a comprehensive trade agreement, which is a necessity if we are going to have a bilateral agreement. The third issue that I wish to raise-and I wish to express a great disappointment about the way in which the parliament has been treated in this case-is the Treasurer’s statement of last week about Australia’s demographic challenges. I honestly do not know where he delivered MAIN COMMITTEE his address-that is only because I have not done the proper research-but what I know is that it was not done in the parliament. And if this is such an important issue, as perhaps quite rightly the Treasurer has flagged, then this place is the venue where this should have been discussed. WhilstI note that a couple of the papers that were released at the address allow for public discussion, this address clearly could have been a ministerial statement. Again, there has been a missed opportunity to use the venue that the parliament provides for the proper discussion. If it was good enough for the Treasurer to release his Intergenerational Report at the time of the 2002-03 budget and if this is a work in progress that arises from that, it should have come in to the parliament. As I understand it, none of these documents that were released last week have become parliamentary papers. They actually have no status within the parliamentary procedures, and this is a great disappointment. I would love to have the opportunity directly, not through asides during this debate, to give my comments about the lack of direction that I think these documents show about Australia’s demographic challenges and to properly debate the meagre propositions that the Treasurer has put forward as solutions: the notion that we should work till we drop and things like that. This is an issue that should be debated. It should have been presented as a ministerial statement; the papers should be parliamentary papers that are open to discussion. Finally, the fourth thing I want to raise to illustrate my disappointment about the way in which the parliament is not being used properly is to touch upon Indigenous health. The week before last, the Australians for Native Title and Reconciliation held a conference about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health. The Indigenous health rights campaign launch I think was on 18 February. Directly, my interest in this arises from my membership of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs when it produced its report, Health is life: a report on the inquiry into Indigenous health. At the time, we wanted to make sure that this was the last time that there was a need for such a report and that we set out the basis for the way in which Australia could go forward with its Indigenous people to improve the health of those Indigenous people. When this committee inquiry was launched there was some suspicion that it was an attempt in some way to be negative about what was going on with a clear inference that perhaps there had been excessive expenditure which had drawn little results in the improvement of Indigenous people’s health. Clearly, our inquiry showed that the additional amount of money that is spent on the health of Indigenous Australians is actually meagre when compared to nonIndigenous Australians. At the ANTaR launch two weeks ago, the AMA’s 2003 report card says that the level of health spending for Indigenous people is 22 per cent higher than for nonIndigenous people, but the need is 200 per cent greater. Really it is not surprising given the state of Indigenous Australian’s health that there would be an additional amount being placed at the disposal of those charged with improving the health of Indigenous people. But it is minor; that amount is minor compared to the need. We really have to face up to that. After the committee’s report Health is life in May 2000, it disappointed me to read the speeches and papers delivered at the Indigenous health launch on 18 February. There was a speech, for instance, by the AMA President Dr Bill Glasson that says things like, ‘We should ask ourselves why Indigenous Australians are admitted to hospital at twice the rate of nonIndigenous people?’ He said in his speech: MAIN COMMITTEE I believe all Australians should ask the question why one group of people in our community faces a health reality worse than people in many third world countries. In their report card, there is a graph, and it shows the relationship between the percentage of the Australian population as a whole expected to live to age 65 and the percentage of Aboriginal Australian males and Aboriginal Australian females expected to live to age 65. The figures for Aboriginal people are below the figures for people in countries such as Nigeria, Nepal, Bangladesh, India, Thailand and Vietnam. I seek leave to incorporate the graph in Hansard. Leave granted. The graph read as followsIndigenous health today-I owe it to a lot of people that helped the committee’s inquiry three or four years ago to return to these items-I make the point that my disappointment is that we do not discuss this issue enough in these venues, whether it be the Main Committee, the main chamber or the Senate. This is something which should always be in the eyes of the Australian parliament. The report of the committee in 2000 suggested that there be annual reporting to the parliament. The reason for this was deliberate: it was so that these facts would be in our faces as legislators so that we could not ignore them. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 4 2003 2004 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 2 2003 2004

speaker: Mr Jenkins
theText: I thank the honourable member for Wannon. In these brief remarks aboutWhen you look at the facts on the AMA report card, you see that diabetes is eight times higher, respiratory conditions are four times higher and circulatory conditions are three times higher for Aboriginal Australians than they are for the rest of the population. The life expectancy of Indigenous Australians is still 20 years less than it is for non-Indigenous Australians. When we compare that figure to the figure for comparable countries, such as the United States and New Zealand, we see that the gap is only five to seven years. And they believe that they have a problem. They understand that that is not good enough. But why is there such a disparity? Why is there a disparity of something like 15 years in the outcomes? We need to make sure we have discussions about how we can best improve the way in which Indigenous communities can best deal with these problems. This has to be a partnership. We cannot let the events of a couple of weeks back in Redfern cloud our judgment about the ability of Indigenous communities to deal with these issues. When they put forward their view about what is required, we need to listen to them and we need to act upon those suggestions. When people come forward, like at the launch of ANTaR, we should listen to them and work with people who are working in the area to make sure that we improve the things that deal directly not only with health but also proper housing, access to employment and, most importantly, their sense of belonging and their sense of grievance for past acts. That is one of the conditions that needs to be addressed. In other countries it has been addressed and there are indications that it has led to improved health outcomes. (Time expired) Ms O’BYRNE (Bass) (6.33 p.m.)-It is with a heavy heart that I rise today to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 and associated legislation and to outline the past eight years of this government’s charter, which has included much wastage which has been covered up by even more fibbing. There are significant opportunities now to build a community that provides greater prospects for all its members. But the reality is that this government continues to augment the growing divide between the priorities on this side of the House and those on the other. In my electorate of Bass the constituents that I have are concerned about the issues that affect their daily lives-the issues that this government continues to sweep under the mat through its refusal to treat them as significant. These issues are appropriate access to health care, access to education, access to appropriate employment, access to a high standard of aged care, as well as looking after the environment, safety in the home and community and being able to properly care and provide for their own families. At the beginning of this year a Roy Morgan research poll of Australians showed that the divide between Australia’s richest and poorest was continuing to grow-a trend the Australian Council of Social Services believes is related to rising levels of crime and disparities in literacy and other basic life skills. When these results were published, ACOSS President Andrew McCallum said: The rich-poor divide should not be made worse by the major political parties using the budget surplus and a federal election to offer some voters a tax cut. This would mean the poorest people in this country-those who don’t have a job-will get no benefit from a cut. At the same time the capacity of our national government to address urgent problems in health, education and welfare would be reduced. He suggested that it would be of much greater benefit to turn around this divide in more practical ways, such as using the budget surplus to help lowand middle-income families by imMAIN COMMITTEE proving the family tax benefit system, to get help to those people who need it most; use it to improve the value of rent assistance for jobless people and reduce the impact of housing related poverty; to increase the opportunities for job training, whether through increased TAFE and university places or through greater real work opportunities; to enhance universal health care services such as bulk-billing for a doctor; or for equal access to education. These types of solutions are sensible solutions to problems that are significant to the people of Bass and the people of Australia. These are, in fact, the types of solutions that the government itself had identified previously in its work and family policy documents, which have recently been discovered in leaked cabinet documents-documents that the government is now seeking to cover up. They are solutions that were discarded by a government more interested in spending much-needed money for social services on increased defence capability and security measures-a decision that has only served to destroy the government’s credibility and highlight its disregard for the Australian people. However, these solutions included things like more flexible working arrangements for women returning to the work force from parental leave, and addressing the hardship created by inconsistencies in the family benefits system. But instead the government chose to allow families to continue to fend for themselves, while the Prime Minister played cowboys and Indians in the United States. While the Prime Minister has been off playing deputy sheriff, he has left his ministers home alone-and oh, dear, what a mess they have made while they have been left alone. The government’s ministers have succeeded in utter mismanagement and waste of funds in all essential services. They have succeeded in reprioritising what should be the government’s agenda-that is, the insurance of the well-being of all Australians. The Minister for Health and Ageing, when he speaks about health, has gone one step further towards completely destroying access to health care services, while the Minister for Education, Science and Training has managed to further alienate Australian students who have worked hard for a place in a university-not to mention the Minister for Ageing, who it appears has great difficulty finding anybody who will play nice with her. The latest bulk-billing figures were released recently and again show a drop in the percentage of people who are able to access a bulk-billing doctor. The national average has now dropped a further 3.1 per cent to 66.5 per cent, and in Bass it is sitting now at 43.6 per centthe lowest in Tasmania. If the government really believes that its MedicarePlus policy will have any benefit for providing appropriate health care services then it is even more out of touch than anyone could have previously thought. The MedicarePlus policy will do nothing to solve falling bulk-billing rates. Bulk-billing rates have been failing consistently under this government, and everything it does completely undermines getting access to a doctor. This policy further takes away the universality of the Medicare system and discriminates against those not in the lowest socioeconomic group. It will advance a two-tiered arrangement, where people will fall through the cracks, unable to access any type of health service. It is not good enough that the government continues on its path to create two-tiered systems in all our basic services-systems that only lead to further increases in the divisions between the richest and the poorest in our communities. Another developing two-tiered system is the education system, a system where wealthier families are able to buy places in universities while the number of HECS places for the not so wealthy families, whose children have MAIN COMMITTEE worked hard through their secondary school years to earn a place on merit but miss out because of decreases in funded places, has declined. However, the government has assured us all that there was a definite increase in the number of places, and in fact says it increased the number of places at the University of Tasmania by 1,003. It appears that it is a little confused here. If the government funded an extra 1,003 places at the University of Tasmania, how does that explain the fact that the number of students who missed out on a place this year was 1,606, compared to the 1,416 students who missed out on a place last year? By most calculations, this is actually an increase of 190 students-or 13.4 per cent-who missed out. It seems that the government has been tricking us and has not really created an extra 1,003 new places but has reallocated existing places that were previously funded on the cheap. The government has a dismal record in education policy. It has no commitment to ensuring talented students have access to affordable education. Its only education commitment is towards a user pays system-a system that destroys the opportunity unless you can pay for it. Of course access to a university education, while important, is not a priority for everyone, and in Bass there are many more people who are concerned because they cannot get access to TAFE courses and appropriate job training courses. Even in an environment where there are significant identified skill shortages, many younger people cannot get into skills based training because the government simply refuses to fund the appropriate training facilities. The government also continues to prop up the Job Network system despite it being a significantly flawed financial model that the minister and the government continue to throw even more money at in an attempt to bail it out. The Job Network continues to fail the long-term unemployed, and data collected through the Department of Family and Community Services shows that the number of people who have been unemployed for more than a year is up by almost 6,000 since November last year. In Bass the unemployment figures are currently sitting at nine per cent. How does the government expect to help people back into the work force when it continues to slash labour market programs by $1 billion a year? How can we be expected to trust the government to assist unemployed people if it continues to do a slash and burn program on all the programs that are in place to help them? The other area causing major concern in my electorate is that of aged care. We look forward to the elusive Hogan report into aged care services-the report commissioned by the government, the report that has so far cost $7.2 million, but the report that the minister refuses to release. Interestingly, today, Professor Hogan, the author of the report has started to talk about it himself, probably getting fed up with the government not doing it. In Bass, aged care services are in trouble. There are currently 11 aged care services in the north-east and the providers hold grave fears that if the government funding is not increased then many of these services will simply not be able to remain operational. These services are telling me that there is a real danger that many Tasmanian services will have to close their doors because they are not able to remain financial under the current subsidies. It is not just closing businesses; it is closing people’s homes. In Tasmania, service providers have identified issues like funding equalisation as significant because it essentially means that the funding for Tasmanian aged care services will continue to decrease in order to bring the national funding level into line. It is not a bad idea to have a national funding adjustment but it should be done so that states are not disadvantaged. It is not a viable option MAIN COMMITTEE when the subsidy rates in one state are decreased leading to a significant difficulty in maintaining the current standards. These reductions are really hurting aged care services in Tasmania. They are impacting on the ability of services to not only maintain the level of care they are renowned for but also to simply survive. This is a point that has been further compounded by the decisions by the Salvation Army to sell off 15 of its 19 aged care services across Australia and the Seventh Day Adventist Church to sell its two services in Tasmania. These are decisions that have caused great distress to organisations that have done excellent jobs in the provision of a high standard of aged care over the years but which now say that they can no longer viably and with good conscience provide such services. The Seventh Day Adventist Church has already sold its services to the Presbyterian Church, which continues to provide services to its residents. The Salvation Army is now in negotiations with prospective buyers for Tyler Village, which provides a home for 75 residents and employment for 85 staff in Launceston. With such organisations saying that the system is unmanageable, what hope is there for a robust future for the aged care industry under this government? The government also has to stop treating older people like second-class citizens. The services that the government is refusing to fund appropriately are people’s homes; they are part of their lives. The government must stop its dehumanisation of older people and release the report into aged care services so that it can start engaging in the debate about the best way to appropriately fund and manage aged care services, not about the best way to get out of it. Let us be frank: why stop at older the people? This government really has to stop its complete disinterest in anyone who cannot directly contribute to its election coffers. Take the treatment of essential services in regional Australia as a point in case. The government recently saw it as necessary to close the Launceston Bureau of Meteorology because it was apparently not cost-effective. However, an unexpected community outcry saw it making policy on the run again and it decided at the same time to suddenly open a shopfront experiment in order to pacify the locals and stop the community backlash about the loss of more regional services and more regional jobs. What is really interesting is that in estimates, only three days before, the bureau made no mention of any future plan to set up a shopfront. Yet, after severely underestimating the reaction that such a closure would have in Launceston, they have suddenly announced plans that were apparently on the agenda for a very long time. This decision has been made in order to satisfy the reported 15 per cent funding cut across the board, at least in Tasmania, that the government has enforced-cuts that are part of an ongoing budgetary squeeze by the government, which includes refusals to fund staff pay rises or even supplement pay rises cuts that have seen the bureau’s budget dwindling ever lower since they were forced to take action, in this case, to downsize services or, as Dr Love called it in estimates, ‘de-man.’ Based on this, the government must be asked how it can justify or clarify its $27 million fit-out for the bureau’s Melbourne head office as a cost-effective measure, while the salaries for three positions in a regional weather office are not. I am told that the bureau had no consultation with the Launceston office about its decision to centralise services in Hobart. It was a decision made at a management level for an economic reason and a decision that in turn significantly increases the workload in the Hobart office. Staff down there have not been consulted, so they do not know how they will provide the service either. MAIN COMMITTEE How will the government ensure that the local weather information accessed by the Launceston community, such as farmers or the local winemaker who calls the office each year to discuss the forward forecast at length, remains? The winemaker plans his grape picking schedule by this forecast. What about the marine industry, the professional fishers, the builders and the myriad outdoor occupations that rely on the quality daily contact they have with the Launceston office? How will these professionals have access to the same standard of service from an overworked, overloaded and unconsulted team based in Hobart with very limited local knowledge? Professional meteorologists are telling me that replacing people with automatic instruments is not the answer. Instruments cannot report visibility or the extent of mist or fog and they cannot identify cloud types or distinguish between sea state and swell height. This decision should not be based purely on economics; it should also be assessed as a significant safety issue, as well as an industrial issue. And while the government has said it will create two new positions at the shopfront service, it has said that the current staff who hold their jobs and have held them for some time will have to reapply for those jobs, because it refuses to transfer them over. It is unfortunate that, as an economic issue, the government is assessing the future of the Bureau of Meteorology, particularly because of the impact on regional areas. The Launceston office was first, but I understand that there are in fact plans to possibly shed up to another 140 jobs across all the regional weather bureaus. This type of action would be a terrible blight on regional areas not only in terms of the loss of employment in regions but also because of the loss of essential regional services-services that should not be centralised to the nearest capital city. Another example of how this government carries out its consultative processes is the National Airspace System. This is a system that has been one calamity after another, and I am sure members are aware that I have followed this quite closely. It is a completely inappropriate system for Australia’s airspace. It was introduced with no consideration of industry concerns. It is missing vital safety information and there has been no appropriate training or assessment for pilots. The National Airspace System has essentially turned Australia’s airspace into what has been described as an unprecedented unsafe operating environment culminating in what was a serious near miss in the airspace above Launceston on Christmas Eve last year. This incident lead to a review of the system by the government’s own Transport Safety Bureau, which found that the National Airspace System posed a safety risk and recommended a review. It has also led to the announcement yesterday that AirServices Australia is planning on moving a transportable radar unit to Launceston to assist Melbourne based air traffic controllers and to increase aircraft surveillance over Tasmania. This system is normally stored in Melbourne, but is to be kept operational in Launceston because under the current airspace system with the type and volume of commercial and general aviation traffic, the airspace in Tasmania has become unsafe. However, if someone else’s machine breaks down, the Launceston machine will be moved to go and fix up someone else’s airspace, which means we return the Launceston air space to being very dangerous once again. It is frightening that the minister and the government are prepared to put public safety ahead of their stubborn determination to implement such a system. It is a determination which saw the minister convene industry advisory groups consisting only of those people prepared to share his point of view. The Howard government’s cost-cutting agenda is dangerous and raises the question of how we can more effectively leverage regional development through the MAIN COMMITTEE deployment of more government agencies to regional Australia. It also raises the issue of how the government can use its capital assets spend of some $60 billion a year to benefit regional Australia. As a major purchaser of goods and services, the government currently promotes national competitive advantage and Australian and New Zealand industry development. I believe it is time for government procurement policies to be broadened to encompass regional Australia. The government notes that there is a ‘critical strategic role that government procurement plays within the Australian community.’ The rhetoric is not supported by specific procurement policies to assist regional communities. As we know, regional centres are well known for offering cost-effective accommodation options, innovative small business, stability in the work force-and I must say that $27 million will get you an awful lot of office accommodation in Launceston. The government publishes contracts and standing offers with a value of $2,000 or moreand I note that the Department of Finance and Administration publish some extremely highlevel statistics which are drawn from this data. I would like to suggest that the Department of Finance and Administration publish statistics on the amount of government purchasing which is actually sourced from suppliers based in regional Australia. Procurement is being seen as a strategic business tool within the private sector, but not by the Howard government. A more strategic focus on government procurement can result in significant benefits to the Australian community. In fact, every one per cent saving that can be made results in a $600 million benefit. Let us not forget the inefficiencies that exist and the benefits that can accrue from improved procurement practices. While industry is struggling with the cost of tendering in large procurement projects, we are still focused on simplistic initiatives such as putting tenders on the Internet. It seems the Howard government is still struggling with that. After multiple false starts, the National Office of the Information Economy is struggling to get agency support with the latest AusTender initiative. How can we deal with the big-ticket issues when the basics are so hard for this government? Surely we have to move towards establishing an office of strategic procurement to streamline processes and to look for opportunities to maximise the benefit being derived from government procurement. There is a general failing when it comes to the government spending taxpayers’ money. How many examples do we need? Here is another one. How about the Customs Integrated Cargo System, a $100 million blow-out? Even with grant funds, the Howard government just cannot get it right. The government plundered a significant amount of funds through its Networking the Nation program. Many projects are not sustainable and not delivering long-term benefits, through sheer poor management by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Let us be absolutely clear on the poor management of these programs. ANAO audit report No. 12 2003-04 stated that the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts failed to ‘translate the government’s program objectives into operational objectives that would have helped to establish an appropriate performance management framework to monitor the efficiency and effectiveness of program delivery’. ANAO found that the extent of the increase in telecommunications infrastructure development in regional areas would be difficult to demonstrate because no baseline data was collected at the start of the program and so no targets were set. MAIN COMMITTEE Let us highlight the failed Intelligent Island Program that the Howard government trotted out to ensure the passage of the Telstra first tranche. The Tasmanian ICT industry has been conned, jilted and spat out by this government. I have had a constant stream of constituents presenting case after case where the Intelligent Island management has led them up the proverbial garden path, wasting their time and money and with no intention of ever assisting them-just stringing them along. The $40 million allocated to this program would have been better augmented by Commonwealth investment in the Tasmanian Electronic Commerce Centre. We may then have had a sustainable program, a program which could have expanded nationally to provide assistance to other regions right around Australia. But of course the Howard government did not have the foresight, despite the efforts of many to convince them that the Intelligent Island Program was, frankly, not that intelligent. So we are now faced with an Intelligent Island basket case, which people are running around trying to salvage. At least the meagre amounts of funds provided to the Intellinc initiative appear to have been placed in competent hands. This government has had eight years of fibbing and eight years of wasting. Where there is waste, there is a nice little web of intrigue wrapped around it to cover it up. But it is the Australian people who have been the victims of this charade being masked as governance. The Australian people have been the victims of this government’s malady of a reverse Robin Hood syndrome, a syndrome that sees it uncontrollably take from the poor and give to the rich. It is time this government sought assistance for its condition and started to address the myriad problems it has created and the projects it has impaired rather than continue with its agenda of more wastage and more fibs. Ms GILLARD (Lalor) (6.53 p.m.)-I take this opportunity in the wide-ranging debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 to firstly raise an issue of great concern to my electorate of Lalor. It is an issue that members of the House would have heard me raise on a number of occasions-some might suggest on so many that they are perhaps a bit bored with it. But it is an important issue. That issue is of course the future of the Point Cook RAAF base, which is within my electorate. A very important announcement was made on Sunday about the Point Cook RAAF base by the Parliamentary Secretary for Defence, the member for McEwen, Ms Fran Bailey. After years of community campaigning, the Howard government has agreed that Point Cook will remain in Commonwealth ownership and that its day-to-day management will be put in the hands of a trust composed of aviation and heritage groups-including the Point Cook Action Group, Point Cook Operations Ltd, a not-for-profit company which was formed specifically with the intention of becoming a manager of the site, and the National Trust-so that this very special place can be managed in the long term, in keeping with its heritage values and its very great history. The announcement on Sunday has delighted the local community and those who have fought long and hard to see this sort of outcome for Point Cook. I think it is important to remind ourselves that Point Cook is a truly historic site, a site of national significance. As you may be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, Point Cook is the oldest airstrip in the world that is still functioning as an airstrip. It has many of its original features, including hangars and heritage listed buildings. It was established in 1913 as the Central Flying School, and the airstrip has been in continuous use ever since. It is therefore the birthplace of the RAAF and a MAIN COMMITTEE place of international significance, as the oldest airstrip in the world still being used as an airstrip. When we talk about the Central Flying School being started at Point Cook in 1913, it is important that we get some perspective about that, because we need to remember that in terms of aviation history the first ever flight with a person on board took place on 17 December 1903. So a mere 10 years after man’s first venture with flight, Point Cook was operating a flying school, and planes have been flying from there ever since. Apart from having history around the length of aviation service, it is the birthplace, as I have said, of the Australian Flying Corps and the Royal Australian Air Force. It was the departure point for the first north-south and east-west crossings of the continent by air and for the first aerial circumnavigation of the continent. Recognising its historic nature, Point Cook is home to both the RAAF museum and the RAAF chapel. With a site of this significance, which has continuously been in Commonwealth ownership, one would have thought that its future, that preserving its history, would always have been at the forefront of the Commonwealth’s mind, but unfortunately that has not been the case. It was determined in 1997, as part of the Defence Efficiency Review and the Defence Force Reform Program that Point Cook was to be sold, that it was to move from Commonwealth ownership. When I was elected to this parliament in 1998, being aware of the importance of the Point Cook site to the local community, I immediately sought a briefing from representatives of the then Defence Estates Organisation on what was proposed for the future of Point Cook. As we hunched over maps of the site, I was told that, from the point of view of the Defence Estates Organisation, whilst the RAAF museum would continue to operate from the site and whilst they would carve out a heritage precinct that had to be respected, as far as they were concerned, a freehold purchaser of the site would be able to do whatever they wanted to do with the remainder of the site. When I specifically asked them whether that would include closing the site so that it could no longer be used for aviation, they said that that would be all right. When I specifically asked them whether it would be possible for the site to be used for housing development, they said that that would be all right. When I specifically asked them whether it would be possible for the site to be used for industrial development, they said that that would be all right. So, from the point of view of the Howard government at that stage, they were contemplating a future where the oldest operational airstrip in the world would no longer be an airstrip, where the RAAF museum could end up marooned in a sea of housing or incompatible industrial development, and where thereafter the RAAF museum would have been limited to static displays of planes because it would not have been able to engage in heritage aviation and it would no longer have been situated at an operating airfield. Having received that brief, I was rightly appalled. I found that in my local community, in the heritage community across Australia and in the aviation community across Australia, people were as appalled as me and I found that there was already in train a community campaign to try to ensure that Point Cook stayed in the ownership of the Commonwealth, that it was managed in a way which was always compatible with its heritage values and that it operated as an airstrip. The depth of that community campaign can be shown by the fact that quite quickly more than 10,000 signatures were assembled on a petition which I was able to table in the House. In my capacity as local member I brought together the groups that were interested in the future of Point Cook and they were quite quickly able to agree on a vision whereby Point Cook was MAIN COMMITTEE managed by a not-for-profit company formed by aviation enthusiasts and former members of the RAAF. The vision of that not-for-profit company-Point Cook Operations Ltd-was to have Point Cook managed in the long term as an aviation heritage, tourist and educational precinct. This would build on its strengths, its heritage value, its aviation value, the fact that the RAAF Museum is located there and the fact that flight training was occurring from Point Cook then, and continues to occur there now through RMIT. That was the vision that people were prepared to very actively campaign for. I should note the following individuals as people who have put in huge service to this community campaign: Mark Pilkington, who has led the Point Cook Action Group, the preservation society that has always had at the forefront of its activities ensuring that Australia did not lose this historic asset for all time; Peter Scully; Gary Westley; and Brad Owens. Each of them contributed to Point Cook Operations Ltd and to bringing its vision of the site together. Each of them, particularly Peter Scully, contributed to very active lobbying of members of parliament to ensure that people understood the true significance of Point Cook. If members are ever passing through or are in the vicinity of my electorate of Lalor-they are welcome, as long as I know they are there and what they are doing!-one of the things they should do is visit the RAAF Museum. They should meet there my friend Dave Gardner, who is the director of the museum, and they should take the opportunity to experience the history that lives and breathes all around you when you are at Point Cook. I say congratulations to each of the people who has been in a leadership role in this community campaign. Their work saw fruit on Sunday when the Parliamentary Secretary for Defence agreed that this community campaign had had the right idea all along and that Point Cook should be kept in Commonwealth ownership and should be leased for the longer term to a trust. Active in that trust will be the stalwarts of this campaign: people from the Point Cook Action Group and people from Point Cook Operations Ltd, who will be able to manage the site over the longer term in a way that is compatible with its heritage and aviation values and builds on its strength as a tourist and educational precinct. That is a very important issue from the point of view of my electorate. I now turn from a local good news story to something that is in no way a good news story, but I think it would be remiss of me in my capacity as shadow minister for health not to take this opportunity to make some comments on the Medicare issue. I want to talk particularly on the sham safety net, which is at the forefront of the health policy debate, particularly in these two sitting weeks. I think we are all aware that our colleagues in another place are presented with making decisions about the sham safety net in the coming sitting days. I want to take members through what I think it is important to acknowledge in the debate about the sham safety net. From Labor’s point of view, we think our challenge in the coming few weeks is to save Medicare from opposition. Of course Labor will save Medicare from government. We are used to getting into government and saving universal health systems that have been destroyed by conservative governments, but in the next few weeks we have set ourselves the task of saving Medicare from opposition. If we are to save Medicare, it is vital that the Senate rejects the health minister’s political fix-the so-called safety net that is up for debate at the moment. The failure of the Howard government to attend to bulk-billing rates and ensure that specialist fees are fair and reasonable has meant that out-of-pocket costs are rising. MAIN COMMITTEE For the Howard government the sham safety net is the solution of choice. Why is that? Despite the fact that ‘safety net’ are pleasant sounding words, this is yet another policy from the Howard government which is infected with its values and is another policy stepping stone on the path to the dismantling of Medicare. I want to take people through the absurd policy that this sham safety net is if you look at it in detail. First, we need to debunk the Howard government’s spin about the benefits of the sham safety net. The truth is that, on the Howard government’s own figures, only 220,000 families or individuals will benefit from the sham safety net in a year. I note that the Minister for Health and Ageing is actually even revising those figures downwards. Professor John Deeble, one of the architects of Medicare, has said, ‘A generous estimate of the percentage of Australians who will benefit is three per cent and it could well be closer to two per cent.’ Professor Deeble also says that of those who could benefit half would be better off under current arrangements than under the sham safety net. Specifically, Professor Deeble has calculated that the safety net benefits under the Howard Government’s proposal would exceed those under the current system only for services billed at more than 25 per cent over the scheduled fee. On the basis of current GP, specialist and diagnostic fees, this means that well over half of the 220,000 people who reach the threshold would be better off under the current arrangements rather than under the proposed new sham safety net. Professor Deeble says that the proposal to cover 80 per cent of actual fees without limit is effectively uncapped gap insurance, and he is right. This is an admission that the Howard government is both unwilling to increase benefits and unwilling to do anything to ensure specialist fees are fair and reasonable. Who wins and who loses in this situation? We have 97 per cent of Australians getting nowhere near the sham safety net. Of the three per cent who notionally benefit, Professor Deeble says that 1.5 per cent are actually better off under current arrangements. An important point to note is that for the 97 per cent of Australians who do not get on the sham safety net, the situation does not remain neutral because it is those very Australians who will bear the impact of increased fees that occur because of the inflationary cycle started by the expectations of the sham safety net. All of the data from all around the world says that with these sham safety net arrangements there is a price inflation effect on doctors’ fees and specialists’ fees. The 97 per cent of Australians who do not get anywhere near the sham safety net are actually worse off because they end up being slugged for higher doctors’ fees and higher specialists’ fees. We have a sham safety net where 97 per cent of Australians lose and of the three per cent who are notionally better off, half are actually better off under current arrangements according to Professor Deeble, and it costs $266 million: A $266 million plan to make 97 per cent of Australians worse off and, at best, 1.5 per cent of Australians will benefit. Even talking about 1.5 per cent of Australians benefiting is misleading. You have to be $500 or $1,000 out of pocket before you can begin to benefit and who benefits is subject to all sorts of perverse and unfair outcomes. Use of medical services is skewed. While most people have five or fewer consultations a year, a small number of people account for the vast majority of services. Of 220 million Medicare services in 2001-02, 81 per cent were for people who had 10 or more services in that year. A quarter was for people with 40 or more services. These people are much more likely to be poorer than those who saw the doctor only five times a year. The two categories chosen to receive the lower threshold-concession card status or receipt of family tax benefit A-are a poor measure of health need. After all, the family tax benefit system was set up to MAIN COMMITTEE address another set of problems and issues entirely and there is considerable evidence that even health care cards are not an accurate measure of need. The selection of these two categories particularly discriminates against those without dependent children and low-income individuals, while providing significant benefits to many higher income families. For example, a self-funded retiree couple of pension age earning up to $80,000 per annum is eligible for a health care card and hence for the $500 safety net, but a working couple without children earning the same amount will only be eligible for the $1,000 threshold. An individual working full-time earning $35,000 per annum who has a chronic medical condition will enter the safety net only after spending $1,000 out of their pocket, but a self-funded retiree of pension age earning up to $50,000 will qualify for the lower threshold. The Howard government have managed to cook up a $266 million plan to at best benefit 1.5 per cent of Australians, and the tests that they have set up will not even pick the most disadvantaged 1.5 per cent. Then of course $72 million of the $266 million is wasted in administration costs. It is such a poor use of precious health dollars: $72 million gone in administration costs; 97 per cent of Australians lose out; 1.5 per cent who notionally gain would be better off under current arrangements; and 1.5 per cent notionally benefit-and they have picked the wrong 1.5 per cent. All of these practical objections should be enough to stop this latest political patch-up job going through the Senate. But there is also a bedrock principle objection to this sham safety net. This sham safety net is all about distorting from a universal health system to a welfare system. It is all about enabling the Howard government to justify henceforth its failure to invest in Medicare, its unwinding of the Medicare system and its allowing of Medicare to wither and die. And it will do all of that under the cover of saying, ‘Don’t worry. We have a sham safety net arrangement.’ Ultimately, as the universal health system dies, we will end up with a health system like America’s with private provision at the centre and sham safety net arrangements for people who are thought to be poor. And we know how badly those arrangements work in America. Anyone, including any senator, who professes a belief in Medicare cannot endorse this sham safety net arrangement. All it will do is assist the Howard government in destroying Medicare. In and of itself it benefits very few, has unfair outcomes and is a bureaucratic monster. is here. IfI had otherwise been able to do it, I would have had a word to her about the budget appropriations here of $14.3 million in relation to changes in the hearing services model, because I can trust that I would be able to get some sense out of the shadow minister for health where I cannot get anything out of the minister or the government. They have treated me and other parliamentarians and the people of Australia with utter contempt in terms of the bills that are before us now. I have constituents who can no longer get adequate hearing services directly in Bankstown. I can only guess that this $14.3 million may or may not do anything to affect their situationit may or may not improve it. We are given virtually no indication whatsoever. It is mentioned in passing in one line by the parliamentary secretary. If you go to the bill itself and its papers, there is no more information to elucidate what this is about. Since the government in particular brought in accrual accounting you can look at the bills and the background papers and weep at the prospect of finding any real or substantial information that you would be able to MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 4 2003 2004 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 2 2003 2004

speaker: Mr Hatton (Blaxland) (7.13 P.m.)
theText: It is good to see that the shadow minister for healthhand on to any constituent not only in my electorate but Australia wide. It is extremely difficult to get the information. The government is asking for additional appropriations. There is the normal budget process. These extra appropriations are adjustments to those original expectations of the budget. We in this House are expected to blindly accept the few scraps of information that the government has given us and say, ‘They are budget measures; therefore they should simply be passed.’ The government has not taken the time or made the effort-it has not demonstrated enough concern to inform me or the community at large about the nuts and bolts of what it is doing, which has a deliberate effect and impact on constituents in my electorate. I will go in particular into the question of health services in Bankstown with regard to Australian Hearing and the experience of two of my constituents. I may then go to some other matters. There is an item of $21.4 million in assistance for the victims of the Bali terrorist attacks and their families and for meeting the costs of the investigations. We know what a wicked and cruel act it was for people to have their lives stripped away from them and for people who survived but had horrific injuries. All of us had the opportunity to be with their families at the anniversary commemorations in the Great Hall. This simple line says enough about why this sum of money is being set aside and provided. But in relation to most of the other measures there is very small and partial indication. Let us go to the $14.3 million for hearing services and to the practical problems that are being faced in Bankstown by not just two of my constituents but also many more. Australian Hearing took the time to write politely to Mr Charles Garwood, the constituent concerned. He and his wife had this experience recently. Australian Hearing wrote on 5 December informing him: ... Australian Hearing’s Centre in Chapel Road Bankstown suffered severe damage when a hot water service burst. As the damage was extensive we had to relocate to new premises. They said specifically: You may have received other correspondence suggesting that Australian Hearing was no longer able to offer services to you at Bankstown. That is not the case. Australian Hearing is able to provide hearing services to you in your local area at any of our three new locations listed below including Bankstown. They indicated that these were at Chester Hill, Revesby and a new site, the Town Square Medical Centre in Bankstown Square, opposite Medicare. They apologised for the inconvenience and confusion. What they did not tell my constituent in December 2003 but he found out, to his cost, in January 2004 is that the permanent facility that was damaged was replaced with a temporary facility. In 2003 the Bankstown centre was a permanent site for Australian Hearing, as was the Liverpool centre. When Mr Garwood had problems with his hearing aid he sought help from the Bankstown service. He had been told that those services would still be available but now he was told: ‘Things have changed. Now this is not a permanent centre; it is only here three days a week and we cannot fix the hearing aid on site. We can take the hearing aid from you and in eight to 10 days time, after it has been sent to Liverpool and back’-only seven kilometres or so away-‘we will be able to give you the hearing aid back; or you can choose to go to Liverpool yourself to get it fixed.’ MAIN COMMITTEE Mr Garwood, who I know extremely well, is a war veteran. That is the reason why he is eligible for this help. I will read to the House the experiences he and his wife had in trying to get the hearing aid fixed at Liverpool that day. His wife, Hilda, wrote: My husband aged 83 a War Veteran with a Hearing disability due to being blown up in a War Zone has their servicesthat is, those of Australian Hearing in BankstownHe received a letter dated 5th Dec.03 which I enclose herewith. However the statement of hearing service in the local area is a MISNOMER. My Husband’s hearing aid stopped functioning so we went on Friday the 23rd Jan.04 to Bankstown where we were told there is no such service here we are only a Medical Centre, however if you write your name and address and medical card Number and what is wrong with the hearing aid we will forward it to Liverpool and it will take 8-10 days, but if we were to go to Liverpool they would repair it straight away. That is completely different from the experience that they had. She further states: We decided to do that. It was a very hot day we went by train to Liverpool it was a long up hill walk to the Centre. They repaired his hearing aid in one and a half hours walk back to the station arriving in Bankstown it took from 10am to 4pm before we reached home totally exhausted am sure there are many more people in our age group needing this service in Bankstown. Surely it could be possible to have a repair service at least one day a week. I repeat that last sentence: ‘Surely it could be possible to have a repair service at least one day a week.’ That is a reasonable thing to expect for Mr Charles Garwood, an 83-year-old veteran, and a reasonable thing to expect for his wife, Mrs Hilda Garwood, who went with him in order to get this fixed. Hilda Garwood has visited Liverpool before. She has been to Liverpool hospital. Charlie Garwood, her husband, went to Liverpool hospital time and time again when Hilda was there with a significant heart problem. I visited her there some time last year when she was there for a long period. She had a very significant condition which took her a long time to recover from. To have people in their 80s put out in that way is just not good enough. When the permanent facility had been there for years, it is right and proper that not only the Garwoods but my other constituents could say, ‘If the old centre was destroyed, there should be a permanent centre for Bankstown.’ It is not Woop Woop; it is the centre of Sydney. There are 180,000 people in the City of Bankstown-my electorate has 82,000, Daryl Melham’s electorate has another 82,000, and there are more people as well. Bankstown is a central place in Sydney. It is easier for a lot of people to get to Bankstown than it is to get to Liverpool. They have had a situation where the permanent facility has been replaced with an inferior, temporary one. We have a high aged population in the electorate of Blaxland. Those people who have not had the experience of the Garwoods will no doubt find the same situation applies. I made representations to the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs with regard to this matter, attaching the letter from Mrs Garwood. I said, in part: To replace the Chapel Road Centre, the Australian Hearing Service three days a week occupies a small, claustrophobic room within the Bankstown Square Medical Centre. They provide a limited service, but have to send hearing aids elsewhere for repairs, taking up to ten days. If the $14.3 million here for changes to the hearing service model do not encompass changing from temporary to permanent the Bankstown centre, I suggest to the parliamentary secretary and the minister that that should be undertaken. The significant numbers of people who are MAIN COMMITTEE disadvantaged by the current situation need to have that addressed. It is a big problem for older people. Both the Prime Minister and, more particularly, the Treasurer, recently seem to have discovered the question of an ageing Australia and the difficulties that that will incur for the government in a fiscal sense. But the real difficulties are faced by people day after daynot in 10 or 20 years time, but right now, day after day. If you do not have adequate and proper services it is very difficult for those people who are already, in this case, paying more than $30 a year for the maintenance of this equipment and who have the extra cost, not just monetary but also on their bodies-on their systems and their nerves-of having to go to that kind of trouble. It simply is not right. It is not right that those Australians in my electorate of Blaxland who cannot afford adequate dental care are forced by this government to wait for up to five years to get that care. You will not find any provision of moneys in either the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 or the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 for that dental care. The reason for that is that this is a coalition set of appropriations. They wiped out any future moneys for dental care for the aged and people on pensions and beneficiaries when they concluded the four years of the Keating government program which put an extra $300 million or so into dental care for the aged. As an opposition we have pledged that we will put $300 million of new money towards addressing the very real health problems of Australians living in Blaxland and other electorates where they need the intervention of the Commonwealth government because they cannot get access to proper dental services. Hearing and dental problems are two key difficulties for the aged. Anyone here in this room and anyone listening throughout Australia who has aged relatives or friends would understand the trauma that is caused to them through the loss of appropriate and adequate hearing and the difficulty it entails in terms of dealing with their everyday problems. People would also realise how significant it is for people to have dramatic dental problems that simply are not addressed because they do not have the money. The health impact upon those people who suffer is enormous. The final cost to the community, of course, is extremely significant. If you let these problems build and do not either take preventative measures or have early intervention, dental problems can lead to dramatic problems which can, through abscesses that become extremely severe, occasion hospitalisation and the direct intervention of surgeons in order to fix those problems. I know that I have seen it happen. I have been the victim of dental abscesses. The same problem has happened to my wife. If they get bad enough, you can be one or two days off dying if there is no intervention. I was lucky. In my personal experience, we were able to go and get direct intervention and ensure that we got the treatment that we needed. But there are many people who do not have that recourse. That is why these appropriations should encompass moneys for more than 500,000 Australians who are on the waiting list and who can wait up to five years or more for appropriate intervention to fix their acute dental problems. These moneys are not here, because this government has not only contempt for us in terms of providing information but also utter contempt for all of those people on that waiting list, because it simply says to them, ‘It’s a state matter-you can sit there and wait.’ You can hope that you might get your problems fixed, but the federal government will take no direct approach to this. MAIN COMMITTEE The member for Werriwa, when addressing Labor’s national conference in Darling Harbour, quite rightly took a copy of the Australian Constitution out of his pocket and referred to the section which directly says that both health and dental services are a direct responsibility of the federal government. That was why the Keating government was able to take direct action by supporting a four-year program to fix the problem the states did not have the capacity to fix. That is why it is right, proper and just that Labor has pledged to do so. The only hope, because of the heartlessness of this government, is the election of a Labor government to directly intervene to fix those problems. Representing people in Bankstown, I know that we have had one service after another taken away from us. It does not really surprise me that the full and permanent service of Australian Hearing was converted to a temporary visiting service and that Liverpool has taken over. This government has a set against Bankstown, and it has a set against it primarily because the former Prime Minister was a boy from Bankstown, just like me. Our experience relates to not only the Australian Hearing Service but also the department of immigration, which was completely ripped out of Bankstown-one of the most multicultural areas in Australia. I know that we have a former shadow minister for immigration and also a former Minister for Veterans Affairs-someone who has visited the electorate of Blaxland, who knows how diverse that community is, and knows how crucial it is to have services where they are needed. You will not find those services in Bankstown now, because this government has ripped them out, just like they have taken away the permanent centre for Australian Hearing. You will not find the Australian Taxation Office in Bankstown now-that building is now inhabited by the state police because this government would not provide a full regional tax office, employing more than 650 people, in the City of Bankstown. SoI look forward to Labor coming back to government and I look forward to having services put back into Bankstown, into my electorate, and having appropriations-either budgetary or these extra appropriations-to directly service the people of Bankstown, who have been so badly dealt with by this government, which has treated them with utter contempt. It has done so for no reason other than the fact that the former member for Blaxland happened to be their representative and maybe, as a secondary issue, because I worked for him. WhatI can promise you is this: I trust that the representations that I have made on behalf of Mr and Mrs Garwood-which is just one example of the problems that people have faced with the rolling back of the permanent service of Australian Hearing in Bankstown to a temporary service-will be addressed by the appropriate minister and that it is put back into place, as it should be, so that all of those people in Bankstown who need that service can access it. I hold out no hope whatsoever that this government, which has been appealed to time and time again, will restore full dental service to those 500,000 Australians who need it. I trust that the next Labor government will stick to its pledge with regard to that. If you look at the rest of these appropriations, which have been so poorly dealt with in terms of information, a Labor government will not only give the services back but it will explain why it is being done. (Time expired) tion Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 give members a forum to canvass the issues that are important to our constituents-issues which in many cases are being sadly neglected by this Howard government. I MAIN COMMITTEE
