speaker: Mr Sciacca (Bowman) (7.33 P.m.)
theText: Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, Appropriawould particularly like to use this opportunity to place on the public record my continuing concern about the impact that this government’s spending priorities-priorities that are dramatically out of kilter with those of the general community-is having on individuals and families living in my electorate of Bowman and, indeed, people around Australia. Almost two years ago, in his 2002 budget address, the Treasurer released the Intergenerational Report. He heralded the document as a landmark enabling the government to draft the budget, not simply with a view to achieving shortto medium-term policy goals but also in the context of the ‘challenges that lie ahead for our children, our society and our government’. It seems that when the government asked ‘What do we need to do now to prepare for generations ahead?’ unlike the rest of the community, this government did not look at the report’s prediction that aged care costs would rise from 0.7 per cent to 1.8 per cent of the GDP over the next 40 years, and that by 2031 the number of Australians aged 65 and over would increase from 12.7 per cent to 22.3 per cent of the population. They did not look at those staggering figures and think that health and aged care services are areas in need of immediate attention. As we saw with the Treasurer’s speech last week, they finally realised that it is high time to re-examine pensions and superannuation in the context of our ageing society, but aged care seems to have been left way down the list of priorities. The anecdotal evidence presented by my constituents, who continue to experience terrible difficulties trying to find a place for their elderly relatives in an appropriate aged care facility, is overwhelming. Their frustration is echoed by the service providers themselves. I recently met with Mr David Angell and Ms Anne Livingston of Aged Care Queensland, the peak industry body for aged and community care providers in Queensland. With members drawn from the residential, retirement living and community sectors, Aged Care Queensland has a comprehensive understanding of the issues confronting the aged care industry in Australia. Mr Angell and Ms Livingston identified three crucial areas that need urgent government attention if the quality Australians demand of their aged care sector is to be preserved and the pressing issue of accessibility is to be addressed. Firstly, the industry believes that the Commonwealth Own Purpose Outlays formula, as it currently stands, does not reflect the real staffing and associated costs of operating aged care services. For example, wage compensation is only increased by the amount of the safety net adjustment, bearing no real relationship to wage fluctuations in the aged care sector. Under the current formula, aged care providers are being forced to find a balance between cutting costs and providing quality care-a situation which is unsustainable. Aged Care Queensland stress that, as most aged and community care providers are run on a not-for-profit basis, they are simply unable to afford to subsidise the gap between income and costs on an ongoing basis. The standard of care will almost certainly begin to slip if this situation is not addressed, and we will see more providers follow the example of the Salvation Army and bow out of the sector, as they can no longer operate on a viable basis-at least in some of the states. What the aged care industry is asking for is not without precedent. The Howard government introduced a new indexation formula to rectify a similar disparity between costs and income for services provided by the Department of Veterans’ Affairs. The opposition, on the other hand, realise that it is untenable for aged care facilities to continue to shed staff in an effort to cut costs, thereby blowing out the staff-to-resident ratio. A Latham Labor government would oversee the introduction of minimum staffing requirements in the aged care sector to MAIN COMMITTEE put an end to the current situation, in which the Health Services Union reports that one or two staff members can have responsibility for up to 70 residents at a time. We recognise that our seniors and our aged care workers deserve much better than that. We heard the minister recently claim that the Howard government has increased funding to aged care by 100 per cent, but such a claim is vastly different to the picture painted by the people on the ground in the aged care industry. In an interview on ABC’s AM program of Wednesday 11 February, Richard Gray of Catholic Health Australia said: There’s been inadequate increases in funding for number of years now, and the current funding regime is not adequate enough to meet quality care needs ... Aged Care Queensland estimates that residential care providers are currently around $406 million behind the level of funding needed to meet the real cost increases that the sector has faced since 1997. At the recent summit of the National Aged Care Alliance, industry insiders suggested that an immediate rise in funding of $10 per bed per day is required to bring residential services back to a level at which they can comfortably meet service standards, maintain and upgrade facilities and equipment and retain an adequate-sized and appropriately skilled staff. Of course, residential care is just part of the aged care industry. Many of the older members of the community would prefer to be able to remain in their own homes, living as independently as possible for as long as possible. This is where the third area at the centre of Aged Care Queensland’s concerns comes in-that is, the underfunding of community care. Having absorbed a $120 million gap between funding and costs, the community care sector urgently needs a 10 per cent funding increase to cover the real costs in providing care to the estimated 400,000 aged and disabled members of our community who rely on community care programs. Aged and Community Services Australia, on behalf of respected industry bodies including Alzheimer’s Australia, the Australian Council of Community Nursing Services, the Australian Medical Association, Carers Australia and COTA-the Council on the Ageing-published A vision for community care: a discussion paper in August 2002. The paper observed: There is increasing recognition that community care programs can no longer be considered separately from the myriad of intersecting service sectors, including residential aged care, disability services and primary and acute health services. Changes in any one of these systems inevitably affect the others, as has been the case with the reduction of length of stay in hospitals increasing the care needs of some community care clients after discharge home. If the level of service provided by the community care sector decreases as a result of funding shortfalls, the pressure on residential care and hospital systems will increase. In other words, failure to invest in one part of the system is going to make the whole system less effective. According to the independent report commissioned by the Myer Foundation-2020 Vision for Aged Care in Australia-it is community care in particular that requires a substantial funding boost. The report called for the expansion of community based care with a view to shifting the mix of health care options for older Australians towards a greater availability of community care, including a greater investment in preventative health care and housing features to allow seniors to live in their own homes as long as possible as they age. The report also advocated improved integration between aged and community care and other related services. Similarly, the aged care industry has called for prevention and health MAIN COMMITTEE promotion to be acknowledged as an integral component of community care services. They would like to see the funding system modified so that care is available not only to those with high care needs but also to seniors with less intensive or perhaps less immediate needs to prevent further functional decline. Greater investment in these areas would make a significant contribution to delaying and reducing the need for ongoing services in high-intensity community hospitals or residential care. My friend and colleague the member for Franklin and you, Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, are, like me, at the age where we may be needing those services some time in the nottoo-distant future! Investing in aged care is an investment in the future for all of us. Sadly, with this government we have heard a lot of lip-service but have seen a noticeable lack of action. an inquiry costing some $7.2 million. It was due in December last year. It is now March and we are still waiting for the report to be made public. While the government sits on its hands the aged care industry is left in limbo, with no certainty as to how their funding system will be altered and how that will impact on their capacity to ensure that, when they need it, all Australians can easily access high-quality care. This is a state of uncertainty that will continue once the Hogan report is finally released, while the government takes its time to respond. If the delays we have experienced waiting for the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs to issue a final response to the Clarke report are anything to go by-and, of course, the Prime Minister had to bail her out of that one and made certain announcements today-it looks like we are still at the beginning of a long, drawn out process. It is time for the government to take responsibility-to respond to the calls for action emanating from the industry and the growing numbers of seniors in our community and ensure that the imminent crisis in aged and community care is nipped in the bud. On behalf of Aged Care Queensland, the many dedicated workers in the aged care industry, and the seniors living in the Bayside and Redlands districts-and, indeed, in all of Queensland and Australia. I call on the government to look at these serious funding issues which are facing the aged care industry and act decisively to invest in this important sector and reverse the damage done before the situation deteriorates even further. Frankly, we are seeing the results of massive budget cuts after the 1996 election, when the public voted the Labor government out of power. Another important area in which the government is guilty of sitting on its hands is, of course, that of families and Centrelink benefits. Disappointingly, although fully aware of the problems in this area-as evidenced by the Prime Minister’s address to the National Press Club prior to the last election, which identified balancing work and family as a key priority for his third term, and the leaked cabinet documents that emerged recently setting out the deficiencies of the government’s family policies-the government has nonetheless chosen to do nothing. In the face of a damning report from the interdepartmental work and family task force, made up of representatives from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Family and Community Services, the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations, Finance and Treasury, which was before cabinet way back in December 2002, the MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Sciacca
theText: The Hogan report into aged care pricing, mentioned by my colleague, isgovernment has done nothing. Even though it is aware that second earners in single-income families in the $30,000 to $40,000 income range are paying, for each dollar earned, 60 per cent plus tax and net child-care costs, that to solve the problem of the flawed family benefit system significant changes are needed, that many families have found the precise forward income estimation difficult and that the issue of debts has detracted from community recognition and that features such as this can be perceived by families as having impacts-these are all words used in that report-it has done nothing. My colleague the shadow minister for family and community services hit the nail on the head when he reflected: ... frustrated at the cover up, government bureaucrats have taken matters into their own hands by leaking key cabinet-in-confidence documents. Rod Whyte, formerly a senior manager with Centrelink, has written a book on the long standing and appalling error rate within Centrelink and the agency’s failure to fully investigate the causes of errors which lead to incorrect payment. Imagine that: enough errors, debts unfairly raised against clients who have done nothing wrong and adventures in mismanagement and inefficiencies to fill a book. In an interview with the Australian this week, Mr Whyte said: Many customers over the course of the next 12 to 18 months will pay dearly for Centrelink’s mistakes, mainly through having to pay back sizeable debts that weren’t their fault. Mr Whyte’s criticisms have been backed by the Australian National Audit Office and by literally hundreds of constituents in my own electorate of Bowman who have suffered significant financial penalties due to Centrelink’s inadequate performance. They are people like Mrs Gail Lee of Alexandra Hills, whose dealings with Centrelink have been quite an ordeal. I have written to Minister Anthony about the situation and hope that I will receive his response in the not too distant future. I might mention that I have given up writing to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Patterson, who, although reputedly the senior minister, has forwarded all my past correspondence regarding Centrelink to her junior minister for response. It seems that the government, embarrassed by her efforts in the health portfolio, thought it best to give her a title and pop her in a corner where she can do no harm. As I set out in my letter to Minister Anthony, my constituent’s problems began because of another area in which the government has failed to act to assist ordinary Australians-that is, the rising cost of housing and the difficulties first-time home buyers experience getting into the market. Mrs Lee’s daughter was having trouble getting a housing loan, and so in June 2003 they decided that the mother would transfer the title of her unit into her daughter’s name. This would allow the daughter to present herself at the bank with equity in property so that she could secure the loan she needed to purchase her own house. As a result of this transaction, Centrelink decided that Mrs Lee had gifted away $140,000 worth of assets. Accordingly, the agency deemed her to be earning an income of $90 a week, and on 6 June 2003 Centrelink cancelled Mrs Lee’s entitlement to widow allowance. This decision was taken even though, under the income test, my constituent should still have qualified for a partial widow allowance and, under the assets test, as a non home owner, she also continued to qualify for this allowance. The decision meant that she was left without any income. She was left destitute. She was forced to sell her furniture and rely on the generosity of family and friends in order to survive. Fortunately, Mrs Lee was able to secure temporary employment, but that position no longer exists and she is left again without any income. My constituent has advised me that, although MAIN COMMITTEE she contacted Centrelink by telephone and in person, on three separate occasions she was refused any recourse or right of appeal against the decision taken in her case. By giving out misinformation like this, Centrelink not only undermined my constituent’s basic right to seek a review but caused her undue stress and financial hardship. Unfortunately, it was not the only incorrect information given to Mrs Lee. She was also told that, in her circumstances, she would not qualify for a low income earners’ health care card, yet when eventually she decided, given that she had nothing to lose, to put in an application she received the health care card she had been entitled to all along. When my office contacted Centrelink about my constituent’s situation, they had another look at her case and discovered that, instead of treating Mrs Lee as a non home owner, her entitlement to widow’s allowance had mistakenly been calculated and declined on the basis of the home owners asset threshold. But, because my constituent was incorrectly advised of her review rights and tried to make her own way as best she could before, in desperation, she sought the assistance of my office, she is outside the three-month limitation period to obtain any compensation for the loss she has suffered as a result of Centrelink’s negligence. It is nothing short of disgusting that my constituent, through no fault of her own, has suffered months of stress, has been forced to sell off most of her assets simply in order to survive and is left with no course of redress, no back pay and no apology. Centrelink will not even reinstate her widow allowance because, having re-entered the work force, her circumstances have shifted and she would only be eligible for Newstart payments even though her position existed only briefly. As I mentioned earlier, I am hoping to receive a response to my representations soon and I hope that, in his response, the minister acknowledges the glaring inequity of the situation and acts to ensure a fair solution is found to Mrs Lee’s problems which have occurred as a result of Centrelink’s repeated errors in dealing with her situation. This is the story of just one of many of my constituents who contact my office every week who are suffering as a result of this government’s cutbacks, and it is just one of the many reasons why I support the second reading amendment moved by the member for Fraser which condemns this government for its budget waste, mismanagement and wrong priorities. As a former parliamentary secretary in the area of social security for something like four years, I know the dedication and work that is done by people that work at Centrelink, which used to be known as the Department of Social Security. In the vast majority of cases, they are good people. They do a good job and they help out as much as they can under very adverse circumstances. I must say that it must be absolutely trying for them with all these cutbacks and the amount of money that is taken away by the government from these sorts of services. We heard my friend the member for Blaxland talk about how many services had been taken away from his electorate. I think just about every Labor electorate in Australia can say that that is the case. Medicare offices have closed all over the place and people have been forced to use expensive transport just to go and get a few dollars back. The reality is that it is not the fault of the public servants. I want to make that very clear here today. It is not the fault of the public servants; it is the fault of the government that does not give them enough money and tries to cut back. Now we have Mr Howard repeating the scenes of 2001, starting again to see if he cannot flip-flop on issues and start to buy the next election. You can see it happening now the way it did in 2001. But I say to him: ‘Don’t just do it at election time. Pay the money out. Give it back to where it belongs. Don’t forget that governments are here to service the MAIN COMMITTEE electorates and the people in this country.’ It is about time that we started getting back to reality. It is about time we started spending money on the services that the Australian public needs. Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 by the member for Fraser, which amendment covers the following vital family areas: (1) a costly Medicare ‘safety net’ which does not protect families from increasing health costs and the declining level of bulk billing; (2) inadequate funding and higher fees for students seeking access to higher education; (3) a growing number of families who are financially squeezed and trying to balance work and family; and (4) 500,000 Australians waiting for up to five years to get their teeth fixed. The most important area of policy in Australia is the need to protect families. This is the direction that the Australian Labor Party is taking under the new Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham. BeforeI cover those points as I go through my speech, I point out that today, 2 March, marks the eighth anniversary of my election to parliament. My intention is to take stock of the issues in my electorate. I have revisited what I said in my first speech and in other earlier speeches to see what I considered important then, comparing them to the major issues of today and how these have been addressed over that eight-year period. One matter I mentioned in that very first speech was the massive residential development that was expected to take place in the northern part of the Greenway electorate around Parklea and Rouse Hill. I said on that occasion: The first stage of the Rouse Hill development centred on the Parklea release area is currently in the early stages of development and is eventually expected to house 50,000 people. This development has taken place as I predicted, and it is still taking place. Nearly 60,000 new residents have come to call Blacktown city home over the past 10 years. The local council has approved over 10,700 new dwellings in the past five years alone, the majority of which have been in the Greenway electorate. At 285,000 people-and growing by over 5,000 people each year-Blacktown city is the largest local government area in New South Wales and the third largest in Australia. Between the 1996 and 2001 census, Blacktown had the second largest growth of any LGA, and one in every 70 Australians now call Blacktown home. I have seen my electorate grow in its population but shrink in its geography. This massive residential growth, as you can appreciate, Mr Deputy Speaker, has placed a considerable strain on the infrastructure needs of the region and, while much has been achieved, there is still very much more to be done. Mr Deputy Speaker, you can appreciate again that that area of infrastructure covers the whole spectrum of health, education, transport and roadworks. Much of the infrastructure work that has been completed so far has been carried out by the state Labor government. Windsor Road, which anyone from Western Sydney would be aware of, has been upgraded, but this was a long-time source of irritation and frustration to local motorists. Marayong railway station, the centre of an expanding area, has also been upgraded, with a modern lift complex to cater for wheelchair access, and the rail track has been duplicated to Quakers Hill, improving the rail service to that station. I called for this in my first speech in this place. Local residents now look forward to the completion of the duplication of MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 4 2003 2004 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 2 2003 2004

speaker: Mr Mossfield (Greenway) (7.53 P.m.)
theText: I rise to support the amendment moved to thethe rail line right through to Riverstone, which is the last station in my electorate. Another project that urgently needs attention is the upgrading of the Quakers Hill railway station. As I said, much more needs to be done. Blacktown Hospital has been completely rebuilt by the state government and is now considered state of the art. One other issue of infrastructure that I need to comment on is the Western Sydney orbital or, as it will become known when it is completed, Westlink M7. I have been a long-time strong advocate of this highway, even before I entered parliament. It is pleasing to see the speed at which it is now finally being constructed. I was also a member of the Greater Western Sydney Economic Development Board-a board of local businesspeople-which campaigned strongly for what we knew then as the Western Sydney orbital. I have supported the various arguments advanced by that organisation and various employer groups that the M7 would improve industrial road transport, which is vital, with many industries operating on a just-in-time principle, and its construction will lead to employment growth in the region. That will definitely be a good outcome once this road network is completed. Unfortunately, the Howard government has ignored its responsibility to the people of my electorate with regard to this highway. The previous government had made plans to finance a certain section of it and had commenced work on it. The M7 will form the last link in the national highway system that stretches over 18,500 kilometres around Australia. Yet the Howard government ducked its responsibility to build it and basically demanded that the New South Wales government build it with a toll. The Howard government has, in effect, privatised the national highway. In some of my earlier speeches I praised the work of the Quakers Hill family service, a joint program between Wesley Dalmar Child and Family Care and the Quakers Hill Uniting Church. This service was working with high-risk disadvantaged families and families in crisis. The 1998 annual report of this organisation indicated there had been increasing demand for counselling for families and children. Part of the stress on these families can be described by paragraph (3) of the amendment which simply says: (3) a growing number of families who are financially squeezed and trying to balance work and family ... This basically comes about because of the high mortgages families now have to contend with. There has also been an increase in the number of families with multiple problems in the area of direct family support. Reflecting on the slash and burn policies of the Howard government at the time, I said in one of my earlier speeches in this parliament: The reduction in department of community services funding as of July 1998 and less child care assistance to subsidise low income families being provided by the department of health and family services have brought changes to the service in the area of vocational care. As a result, fees have needed to be adjusted to accommodate the new system, which is confusing many families. That was clearly a problem that existed in the early period of my time in this parliament. I have here the report of the annual general meeting of 2002-03 for the Quakers Hill family service. The report shows the services the centre has continued to provide for needy families over the past 10 years. In particular, the report lists its future challenges, and I believe they really highlight what is required by low-income people in the area I represent. The future challenges for this organisation include the closing of Sundowner Village, which is a caravan park for low-income people, and the need to maintain a high level of support and advocacy with increased demands for affordable housing. Once again, I compliment the state Labor MAIN COMMITTEE government. I have noticed in the press recently that they have introduced legislation that will make people who occupy these caravan parks a little more secure in their accommodation arrangements, and this is good news. Other future challenges for this organisation include ensuring the sustainability of programs, developing opportunities for growth to reflect the increased population and their service provision needs and increased human services for the Rouse Hill strategic planning area. A challenge for Parklea Prison is a growth in beds from 600 to 1,200 in the women’s wing. Another challenge is the potential explosion in mortgage stresses with interest rate increases. Once again, that reflects the increase in residential development of the area. On a sad note, the report also refers to the passing of Glenys Judd, a previous centre coordinator who, unfortunately, lost her fight against a major illness in January 2003. Glenys and I developed a fairly good working relationship, and I was happy to work through her to assist this organisation. Glenys made a major contribution to the work of the centre and will be sorely missed. I return to the issue of child care, which is a major issue in my electorate. In 1996-97 there was an $820 million cut to child care which has led to increased fees and reduced child-care assistance, low-quality care and the closure of several services. At the time, child-care closures occurred in my electorate in Seven Hills, Marayong, Riverstone and Blacktown. If we move forward to the present day, we can see the results of this short-sighted policy of funding cuts. At a Senate estimates committee hearing in June last year, we learnt that there was a shortage of after school care in the Blacktown local government area of over 1,000 places. This was well in excess of any other area in New South Wales or Australia. The next highest shortfall was in the neighbouring area of Holroyd, which had almost half that number with a 590-place shortage. As I have said, there has been a huge residential development, with a lot of young families moving into the area, yet there has been a reduction in the availability of child-care places. This has come about because of the slash and burn policies of the Howard government in the 1997 and 1998 budgets. Of particular concern is the dramatic shortage of child care for the zero to two age group in Blacktown. The electorate of Greenway has the third highest number of children in this age group, behind the neighbouring Western Sydney electorates of Werriwa and Chifley. This highlights the needs of the child-care sector in our area of Western Sydney. For this reason it is encouraging to see the response of the new Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham, to this crisis. The member for Werriwa has called the rates of pay for child-care workers a national disgrace. He said: At $13 an hour it is impossible to attract the qualified teachers to run the education programs so it’s more than child minding and becomes child development. I think that is a very important statement. It is not simply a question of childminding; it is a question of educating the children and educating their development in these early age groups. The Leader of the Opposition has committed an incoming Labor government to increasing the salaries of child-care workers, increasing the number of child-care places, reducing waiting lists and improving the affordability of child care for parents. IfI could just once again refer to the residential development which seems to be a major theme in what I am saying tonight, a key to sustainable living in the Western Sydney, of course, is more local employment opportunities. I have indicated that I believe the M7 will MAIN COMMITTEE contribute greatly to this. Job growth in the region really has not kept pace with residential growth. In my first speech I said: It is important that we match the training that is available to young people in Greenway and surrounding areas with employment opportunities in local industries and the growth jobs of the future. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 6 June 2003, Bob Myer, of architects Cox and Richardson, who worked for 20 years on the implementation of the Sydney region outline plan-and he lists Parramatta and Campbelltown, but, quite clearly, this would go beyond those two suburbs-said: Job growth ... has been disappointing. Instead tertiary jobs have dispersed in an arc from West Ryde through the CBD to the airport to Botany Bay and people have resorted to private transport to reach their workplace. One of the important points on employment is, of course, the availability of local employment. Once again, the major problem in our area is that people have to travel outside the district to earn a living. One pleasing aspect is that, on information provided by the Blacktown Council, I find that, in 1996, 40.3 per cent of all jobs in the city were held by local residents. By 2001 this proportion had increased to 55.4 per cent. This highlights the increased ability of the city to provide jobs for its residents. Like any location, Blacktown city residential growth will create a demand and requirement for jobs, particularly in service industries such as retail, health, community service and business services. With that in mind, I am very pleased to be able to report that the residential shopping centre at Blacktown is now being redeveloped. I would probably say that this has certainly been long overdue. But it is now being redeveloped under the leadership of Alan Pendleton, the new mayor. Once it is fully developed, this will create additional employment in the area. The commercial development will bring about a total rejuvenation of Blacktown city’s heart and it will be one of Western Sydney’s most significant commercial retail centres. As I said, that will help to increase local employment and provide jobs for local people. With this need in Western Sydney for more employment opportunities, it was with somewhat mixed feelings that we received correspondence from ING Real Estate advising that, with the decision having being made to close Australia’s Wonderland amusement park, the site would now be purchased to create a business park. The problem here of course is that Wonderland will be a loss to the area. It was a major tourist attraction-and out in Western Sydney we do need tourist developments that will attract people into the area and provide employment and amusement for local residents. It was a great employer of local people. There were some 130 permanent and 270 casual workers employed there. The closing of the amusement park will create more pressure on the labour market, particularly in the area of part-time work and young people wanting to get into the work force. So it is a double-edged sword: that is happening and there is going to be pressure there, but on the other hand is the fact that the site will be developed by one of Australia’s largest organisations in this field, with a prediction that there will be some 9,000 jobs created close to where people live. That is definitely good news. I am advised that, under the proposed plan, the industrial business park will be developed using best practice and environmentally sustainable development practices so that trees will be maintained and the natural environment protected. The potential for employment growth is well supported by the education facilities in the electorate of Greenway, which I have spoken about on many occasions previously. MAIN COMMITTEE They are the developments that have taken place over the eight years that I have been the member for the electorate of Greenway. I have seen massive changes. I have seen the state government making a gallant effort to provide the infrastructure that the new residents of Western Sydney need. However, I have seen the federal government cutting back funds, which has reduced medical services in the area. We have seen inadequate funding and the residents in the area that I live in having to pay higher fees for higher education. As I have been speaking about, a growing number of families are financially squeezed. On the one hand we have got the state Labor government providing infrastructure that is needed for the area, and on the other hand we have got the federal government cutting back on the funds that are so vital for the services that we need in Western Sydney. For that reason I am very happy to support the amendment moved by the member for Fraser. priation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 I want to specifically draw on the second reading amendment standing in the name of the member for Fraser, Bob McMullan. In doing so I want to touch on my shadow ministerial responsibilities for transport and regional services and issues raised in the second reading amendment going to the opposition’s condemnation of the government for its budget waste and mismanagement. I draw the House’s attention this evening to the fact that 12 months ago the Secretary of the Department of Transport and Regional Services told his department that they were in a very difficult financial position. I contend that that arose from financial mismanagement and waste by the Department of Transport and Regional Services. The secretary informed the staff of the department that they would run out of money without major changes in the way they operated. The department posted an operating loss of $4.5 million in 2002-03, yet the figure did not tell the whole and honest story. Losses in 2002-03 were in fact more than $4.5 million. With the rollover funds from 2001-02 and forward into 2003-04 taken into account, the operating loss is more like $8.1 million. And this figure does not include the $13 million drawn down from the reserves since 1999. Since then we have discovered that the response of the department and the government to the financial crisis has been to slash staff numbers and freeze expenditure on IT infrastructure, something fundamental to the operation of the department. Across the department the five administrative groups were forced to cut their operating expenses by 10.7 per cent to enable the department to turn around their financial crisis. Two weeks ago during the Senate estimates process we learnt that this whopping productivity increase has fallen squarely onto the staff of the department. The department’s definition of operating expenses appears to be limited to staff costs. We have learnt that staffing levels within the department have fallen by 13.8 per cent in just nine months. In addition, the tools that enable the department to perform its functions-its information technology systems-have had an expenditure freeze imposed on them. This is in spite of the fact that the secretary of the department clearly indicated on 14 May 2003: ... to make ends meet over recent years wethe departmenthave under-invested in infrastructure such as IT desktops. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 4 2003 2004 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 2 2003 2004

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson (Batman) (8.12 P.m.)
theText: In my remarks tonight on the ApproSo not only have staff numbers been slashed by almost 130 but the remaining staff are required to put up with failing IT infrastructure. I think this is fairly important, because the Department of Transport and Regional Services is a very significant department. The staff within the department have been made the scapegoat for maladministration by the Howard government. It did not have to be and should not have been the case. A department properly resourced by government could have continued to provide sound administrative functions. The treatment of staff in the Department of Transport and Regional Services is yet another example of the wrong priorities of this government, its waste and its mismanagement-something that is seen generally across the Howard government. For that reason I very much support the amendment moved by the shadow minister for finance, the member for Fraser that condemns the government for its budget waste and mismanagement and wrong priorities. These have clearly resulted in difficulties with respect to our costly Medicare safety net system; inadequate funding and higher fees for students in higher education; a growing number of financially squeezed families trying to balance work and family; and 500,000 Australians waiting for up to five years to get their teeth fixed, something which is a major problem in my electorate of Batman in the northern suburbs of Melbourne. As a result of penny pinching and the 1980s style corporate management adopted by the government, officers of the Department of Transport and Regional Services are required to perform miracles to achieve government objectives. It is little wonder that the department is falling apart and there are serious problems with respect to the performance of the department, going to such fundamental issues as aviation safety in Australia at the moment. It is little wonder that the department-and, in essence, the Howard government-has not been able to respond to the regional business development analysis report delivered to the government in July of last year. It is little wonder that the introduction of a new IT program management system for the Regional Partnerships program is beset with problems that are leading to increased frustration for program applicants all around Australia. It is little wonder that the Regional Partnerships program has been unable to generate the activity or applications envisaged when it was started in July 2003. As at the end of December this program has only been able to spend less than one quarter of the funds allocated, even though it brought forward more than $30 million expenditure from the previous financial year. The litany goes on across a whole range of activities in the Department of Transport and Regional Services. It is little wonder, for example, that the much publicised AusLink white paper has yet to see the light of day. And it is little wonder that it has taken so long to get even close to the ARTC agreement with the New South Wales state government being nailed down by the federal government going to the upgrade of the national track on the east coast from Brisbane through to Melbourne. And, most importantly, the government’s 20th-century response to departmental administration appears to be designed to silence criticism of the new National Airspace System. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau is the organisation that conducts professional investigations into aviation accidents and incidents. It was the ATSB that first recommended a review of the flawed National Airspace System as a result of an investigation of a near miss incident over Launceston. The recent Senate estimates process confirmed the extent of the MAIN COMMITTEE damage being perpetrated on the ATSB budget and the effect it is having on the preparedness to improve aviation safety for the travelling public. It was confirmed at Senate estimates that the ATSB is investigating only 60 out of 60,000 aviation incidents each year-and this is the organisation that is supposed to assist in maintaining air safety in Australia. This is a very serious issue when you think about the importance of the aviation industry to Australia at large. In 2000-01, the ATSB was funded to conduct 118 new accident investigations, but this has now dropped to just 60. This is at a time when the government is introducing a whole new approach to aviation in Australia. The flawed National Airspace System is slated for fundamental review-and we are cutting back on investigations of aviation safety and near misses in Australia. This is the same airspace system that the ATSB acknowledges is responsible for 27 National Airspace System related incidents since its implementation in November 2003-a very short period. It is the same airspace system that is based on the American model that is clearly unsuitable for Australian conditions, as the near miss over Launceston proved beyond any doubt. I note that, in a recent review of midair collisions in the US, it was found that the most common causal factor identified by the US National Transportation Safety Board was failure to-guess what?-see and avoid. It is interesting to note, as the member for Franklin is well aware because of the near miss in Tasmania just before Christmas, that the National Airspace System being pursued by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services is based on see and avoid and that is the system that we are expected to adopt in Australia. It concluded that see and avoid has inherent limitations as a tactical strategy for avoiding midair collisions. It also found that most midair collisions occur near airports, especially non-towered airports, which is pretty important when you think about regional Australia and the importance of aviation. The use of see and avoid, especially around non-towered airports, is one of the most fundamental changes to our new National Airspace System in stage 2B of the implementation of the NAS system. It is also interesting that during the Senate estimate hearings a fortnight ago the Chief Executive Officer of Airservices Australia dropped his bombshell about the botched implementation of the NAS system-the system that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services continued to tell us in the House only a matter of a week and half ago is safer than the previous operating system. In his statement to the Senate committee on 17 February, the Chief Executive Officer of Airservices Australia said: Airservices recently formed the view that its process for considering the changes on 27 November 2003 may not have properly discharged all its responsibilities under the act. The nature of the gap in our processes relates, firstly, to the extent to which Airservices may have relied on the work of other parties-the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the Aviation Reform Group, the National Air Space Implementation Group as examples-rather than its own comprehensive research and analysis. And secondly, to the way in which we chose to manage an identified risk related to the implementation of class E airspace. I simply say to the House this evening that that was a bombshell and it fell not only on me as the shadow minister but also on the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and his department. The Chief Executive Officer of Airservices effectively stated that the fundamental process for implementing NAS was flawed and hence there were serious questions about air safety in Australia. He stated that, despite the Minister for Transport and Regional Services MAIN COMMITTEE responding in the House on the same day to a question from me by stating that the system was, in essence, the safest in the world. Let us talk about how flawed it is-and that is not my view alone; it is now the view of Airservices and many other professionals in the industry who have long said to the minister, including prior to 27 November, that this system is a risk. I have come to the conclusion that, so flawed is this system as a result of these procedural oversights, Airservices has now undertaken a design safety case for the system’s full implementation last year and it will also undertake a more extensive risk analysis of the changes that were implemented last year. The ATSB has identified that the National Airspace System contributed to a serious incident near Launceston airport in December last year. It appropriately recommended that the National Airspace System procedures and communication requirements be reviewed and, where necessary, there be revision and updating of education, training and sharp frequency material. Then Airservices Australia acknowledged that it had not properly discharged its responsibilities under the act-in effect, it had acted illegally-and it will therefore initiate a design safety case of the full program for reform and also undertake a more extensive risk analysis of the changes. But what have we heard from the person who should be shouldering responsibility for the introduction of the NAS system; what have we heard from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services? I am sorry to report this evening that he has been silent. He has continued to give the House an undertaking that this is the safest system we as a nation could have. The same day that he last answered a question without notice in the House, Airservices Australia-an independent regulatory authority that had belled the cat-owned up to the fact that it had not done the job it was required to do under the act and that the air safety system in Australia, which we depend on, was flawed and had to be completely overhauled. I would have thought that the minister would have made a statement to the travelling public about where this review is up to and why Airservices have had to take it on. I think the minister stands condemned for not accepting those responsibilities and, in essence, not coming clean. But, as far as I am concerned, it is worse than that. The minister has failed to reassure the Australian public that serious incidents like the one in Launceston will not happen again. I think we are entitled to know that that is the view of the minister: that serious incidents such as the one that occurred at Launceston will not happen again-because do you know what that is about? That is about duty of care, from a government point of view. It is time for the minister to fulfil his responsibility by acknowledging the concerns that have been raised time and time again by highly informed members of the aviation industry and by the opposition in parliament and outside. This evening I call upon the minister to accept his responsibility and release a full statement of what really happened with the introduction of the National Airspace System. He must explain why he let Dick Smith, an enthusiastic amateur-his good mate and an even better mate of the Prime Minister-and a known advocate of the US air space model, lead the charge in the design of Australia’s new airspace regime. The minister must come clean on the exact role of the Airspace Reform Group and whether it will start to have another go at trying to fix its botched NAS system. I contend that we need to get rid of the enthusiastic amateurs and hand the review of the National Airspace System over entirely to the experts-the profesMAIN COMMITTEE sionals-and let them do the job, just as they should have been allowed to do it in the first place. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services must also fess up, swallow his pride and let the travelling public know his plans for the future management of Australia’s airspace system. The minister has deliberately hidden from public scrutiny in relation to the changes that he is responsible for and has left the taxpayers to take the blame. This must end. He can no longer hide from his responsibilities. The Chief Executive Officer of Airservices should not have been the fall guy because the minister will not accept his responsibilities. The ATSB should not be forced to accept massive resource reductions in an attempt by the minister to silence the investigator-and this is a very serious accusation. Therefore, on behalf of the opposition this evening, I call on the Minister for Transport and Regional Services to come into the House-if anything I demand that he do so-and explain how and why the National Airspace System has been implemented in the botched way that it has been. The parliament deserves that explanation from the minister and, more importantly, so does the travelling public-and I will tell you why. This is not just about budget waste and mismanagement; it is about the fundamental responsibilities of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. The Commonwealth Minister for Transport and Regional Services has a variety of responsibilities, but a number of them go to the safety of the travelling public, be it a responsibility in the investigation of road and rail accidents or, alternatively, the development and implementation of a safe air system in Australia. This is about duty of care as a minister of the Crown. NAS has put the travelling public at risk. Our air system is not safe, as has been acknowledged by Airservices Australia during Senate estimates just over a week and a half ago. Minister, accept your responsibilities, come clean and help clean up your mess because, if you do not and a serious accident occurs, you will be at fault not only morally but also legally because of a failure to accept your duty of care to protect the travelling public with respect to the implementation and operation of the National Airspace System. I have given the minister sufficient warning and a chance to do what is right by the travelling public. Front up to your responsibilities, Minister: accept your duty of care and do the right thing by the travelling public. Debate interrupted. Main Committee adjourned at 8.33 p.m. MAIN COMMITTEE The following answers to questions were circulated: Immigration: Protection Visas (Question No. 1711) Mr Andren asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 2003: How many applications for temporary protection visas has his Department received from followers of Falun Gong or Falun Dafa and how many of these applications have been approved to date. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: Under Australian migration legislation persons apply for a protection visa and the decision as to whether a permanent or temporary protection visa is granted is made on the facts of each individual case and depends on whether particular regulatory criteria are met. From July 1999 until 30 June 2003 the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) received 4,385 applications for a protection visa from PRC nationals. Of these 4126 have been refused by DIMIA as at 30 June 2003 and a number of applications are awaiting a decision. A substantial number of refused applications have sought independent merits review by the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) of the DIMIA decision. Taking account of cases where a DIMIA protection visa refusal decision was set aside by the RRT, as at 30 June 2003 there have been a total of 125 protection visas granted to this group. tion. Immigration: Protection Visas (Question No. 2000) Mr Kerr asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 4 June 2003: (1) How many detainees at the Curtin Detention Centre have had their applications to the Refugee Review Tribunal refused in the last 24 months. (2) For each instance, can he say (a) what was the date of the determination, (b) what was the date the determination was conveyed to the detainee, and (c) whether the detainee was able to access legal advice by (i) phone, (ii) post, and (iii) in person. (3) Is it the case that when detainees have filled in forms to initiate Federal Court Appeals (without access to legal advice) and posted them in the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs box on site within days of being notified of such decisions, that these documents were not forwarded in time to comply with the mandatory 28 day appeal period so that the detainee was denied legitimate access to the appeal process. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) From1 June 2001 until the centre’s closure on 22 September 2002, a total of 155 immigration detainees had the refusal of their Protection Visa application affirmed by the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) whilst the detainees were in Curtin Immigration Reception And Processing Centre (IRPC).

speaker: Mr Hardgrave
theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs(2) (a)-(b) In only exceptional circumstances, eg detainees in hospital, were detainees advised of the RRT’s determination on a day later than the Department. (c) Detainees have the choice of how they access legal advice. The initial contact is generally by phone and follow-up contact by post. (3) Standard procedure at the Curtin IRPC was that detainees placed their applications for appeal to the Federal Court in the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) box within the mandatory 28 day appeal period. DIMIA checked the box each working day at approximately 8.30 am to ensure that all documents in the box were processed the same day the box was checked. Detainees were continually reminded that they were required to submit their applications with DIMIA prior to the 28 day cut off to ensure that the court would receive the application within the mandatory 28 day appeal period. There were a number of occasions where the court did not receive applications within the mandatory 28 day appeal period. Generally this was a result of detainees placing their applications in the DIMIA box without allowing sufficient time for the applications to be forwarded to the court. However, on a small number of occasions DIMIA’s actions delayed applications, which led to them being received by the court after the 28 day appeal period had elapsed. Where this occurred the Department liaised with the court to seek acceptance of the late applications. On each occasion the court acceded to DIMIA’s request. Immigration: Asylum Seekers (Question No. 2365) Ms Plibersek asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 10 September 2003: (1) Can he confirm that Aladdin Sisalem is being detained at the Manus Island detention centre. (2) Did Aladdin Sisalem request asylum on Thursday Island; if so, what was the legal basis for sending him to Papua New Guinea. (3) What is causing the delay in processing Aladdin Sisalem’s application for asylum. (4) Why is Aladdin Sisalem being kept in isolation on Manus Island when he could be detained on the Australian mainland at less expense. (5) What does the Government intend to do with Aladdin Sisalem when the Manus Island detention centre is closed in October. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Mr Sisalem is the responsibility of the Papua New Guinea (PNG) authorities and presently is accommodated at a facility on Manus Island. (2) He was detected in the Torres Strait in December 2002 attempting to enter Australia unlawfully and was interviewed by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) officials. He did not make an application for a protection visa and was returned to PNG. Australia and PNG have agreed to accept the return of people who illegally cross the Torres Strait without prior written approval from the receiving country. (3) This is a matter for PNG authorities. (4) I understand Mr Sisalem is cared for by the International Organization for Migration (IOM) on behalf of the PNG authorities. (5) Decisions in relation to Mr Sisalem are matters for PNG authorities.

theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous AffairsImmigration: Asylum Seekers (Question No. 2374) Dr Lawrence asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 10 September 2003: (1) How many attempted suicides have there been in detention centres (a) in total and (b) in each of the last five years. (2) What proportion of people (a) in Australia, and (b) in detention centres, has attempted suicide over the last five years. (3) In respect of the water supplied to each detention centre, (a) what is its calcium content, and (b) does it meet the Australian standard for potable water. (4) Can he provide examples of the daily menus at the detention centres. (5) Are different nutritional needs, such as those of children and pregnant women, catered for. (6) Do nutritionists monitor the diets of detainees; if so, are the nutritionists on site or do they review the menus only. (7) Are checks carried out to ensure that prescribed meals correspond with the actual food served by Australasian Correctional Management Pty Ltd (A.C.M). has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Incidents of attempted or actual self-harm are recorded according to the nature of the harm involved, rather than whether or not they may be directed towards suicide. TableA below provides the number of incidents of attempted or actual self-harm over the last 3 financial years. Data prior to this time is not readily available. (2) (a) This information is not held within the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA). (b) Please refer to the answer to part (1). (3) (a) Detailed information on the content of the water is not held within DIMIA and should be directed to the appropriate State Government. (b) The water supplied to each immigration detention facility is provided by the relevant State Government as potable water. (4) An example of the menus at immigration detention facilities is included at TableB below. (5) Special needs diets are catered for, such as for vegetarians, food allergies, children and pregnant women. All children have access to extra fresh milk and other items deemed necessary by the centre doctor; canned baby foods, milk formula and Farex dry baby foods are available for infants; and pregnant women are covered by a pre natal medical care plan which provides a structured nutritional diet. (6) Menus for detainees in immigration detention facilities are reviewed by a qualified nutritionist. Nutritionists are generally not employed onsite, but provide assistance and advice to ensure the appropriate nutritional content is met. (7) The Australasian Correctional Management Pty Ltd (ACM) Food Services Manager, the ACM Centre Manager and DIMIA Contract Managers conduct frequent checks of the menu and served meals. In addition, detainees provide feedback on menus and meals served through detainee representative meetings.

Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 18 September 2003: Further to the answers to questions Nos 1620 to 1635 and 1637 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18168) what are the Chief Executive Officers of the Minister’s departments and agencies doing to ensure that they do not retain the services of any barrister or solicitor who has previously been made bankrupt. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: Engagement of Counsel on behalf of the Commonwealth is subject to the Legal Services Directions. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs requires law firms engaged to provide legal services to comply with these Directions when engaging Counsel. The Australian Government Solicitor has developed a database called the ‘Counsel Engagement System’. When briefing Counsel this Department uses Barristers who are included on this system. In addition, in 2001 the panel firms undertaking litigation on behalf of the Department were instructed to advise us immediately they became aware of any counsel briefed in our litigation becoming bankrupt. To date we have not been so advised. The law firms with which the Department and portfolio agencies have contracts are all major national law firms of high standing. Such firms would not knowingly engage or retain any barrister known to be acting in disregard of their obligations under taxation law. In a number of matters relating to native title, counsel has been briefed directly. Section 203FB of the Native Title Act 1993 requires that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission appoint a reviewer of Native Title Review Board decisions. In some instances a barrister has been appointed as a reviewer. These barristers are appointed as they have the necessary skills and knowledge in relation to the Native Title Act. (2) For each of the last two financial years, (a) what was the cost of processing the stowaways in detention, including the cost of processing protection visa applications, and (b) was any of the cost of handling such unauthorised sea arrivals recovered from the shipping company involved; if not, why not. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) The number of people who arrived by ship as stowaways in the financial years 2001-2002 and 2002-2003 are 29 and 15 respectively. This number of stowaways who came to notice in 20012002 differs from the number previously given in response to Question 2331. The difference reflects an additional stowaway that had previously been incorrectly coded in the Department of

(i) Of the 29 stowaways who arrived in 2001-2002, 10 applied for Protection Visas (PVs) in Australia. Of the 15 stowaways who arrived in 2002-2003, 3 applied for PVs in Australia. (ii) Of the 10 PV applicants in 20012002, 5 are from Iraq, 2 are from the Democratic Republic of Congo, 2 are from Burundi and 1 is from Somalia. Of the 3 PV applicants in 2002-2003, 1 is from Burundi, 1 is from Iraq and 1 is from the Democratic Republic of Congo. Costs vary considerably depending on the time taken to process an application. The average cost of keeping an unlawful non-citizen in a detention centre in 2001-2002 and in 2002-2003 was $160 and $273 per day respectively. Based on volume, the average cost of processing a PV applicant in onshore detention in 2001-2002 was around $3,500. The average cost of processing a PV applicant in onshore detention in 2002-2003 was around $6,000. (b) While the Department infringes shipping companies for bringing stowaways without reporting them on arrival, it does not recover the cost of detention and processing of stowaways who seek protection and make PV applications on arrival. This policy is applied to ensure that there is an incentive to notify the presence of the stowaway. Shipping companies are, however, liable for the costs of removing stowaways whose PV applications have been unsuccessful. Immigration: Special Purpose Visas (Question No. 2726) Ms Jann McFarlane asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 5 November 2003: (1) How many Special Purpose Visas (SPV) have been granted to date in 2003. (2) How many people breached the conditions of their SPVs in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, (g) 2002, and (h) 2003 to date. (3) What action is taken to apprehend a crewmember not holding a SPV who jumps ship. (4) What steps are taken to confine a crewmember not holding a SPV to the ship the crewmember arrived on. (5) Who is responsible for notifying Australian authorities if a crewmember denied a SPV jumps ship. (6) What penalties apply for failing to notify Australian Authorities if a crewmember denied a SPV jumps ship. (7) Does legislation require ships to provide information on their crews prior to their departure from Australia; if not, does the Government seek to obtain this information voluntarily and, if it does, how. (8) Further to the answer to question No. 274, (Hansard, 14 May 2002, page 2139) what action is the Minister taking to secure the passage of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 2002. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Special Purpose Visas (SPV) come into effect through operation of law by virtue of persons holding a prescribed status. No applications are required and no grants are recorded. (2) SPV holders are subject to specific legislative visa limitations. In the case of crew of ships, the limitations are that they must depart Australia within 30 days if they sign off a ship and that while here they are not to perform any type of work other than that normally performed in the course of their crewing duties. As such, if an SPV holder overstays this will be included in other statistical data, as a number may apply for other visa classes. However, some statistics we do hold such as
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Hardgrave
theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous AffairsSPV holders who do not return to the ship come under deserter statistics that we have provided previously. (3) Members of the crew of ships hold a SPV on arrival at an Australian port. If the SPV of a crewmember is ceased the crewmember is normally restricted on board their vessel. If they then leave that vessel, the crewmember is considered to have escaped from immigration detention and normal compliance action is taken. (4) As advised above, crew of ships will normally hold a SPV on arrival at an Australian port. If the SPV has been ceased under subsection 33(9) of the Migration Act, a notice under s.249 of the Migration Act may be issued to the Master of the vessel requiring that they prevent the crewmember from leaving the vessel. (5) Under s.228 of the Migration Act, the Master of the vessel is responsible for reporting any unauthorised absences of members of the crew whether or not the SPV of the crewmember has been ceased. (6) Under s.228 of the Migration Act, failure to report the absence of a crewmember may incur a penalty of up to $4,000. (7) Regulation 3.17 of the Migration Regulations provides that a master of a vessel may be required to provide information on the crew at any time at any port of call in Australia. Australia facilitates the movements of crewmembers into and from Australia through special immigration processing measures. Masters of vessels provide details of any crew joining the vessel while in Australia in order for those crewmembers to access Australia’s special measures. The details of all crewmembers who sign on and sign off ships while in Australian ports are copied to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) for monitoring the crewmembers’ movements. (8) The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 2002 is currently before the Senate. Immigration: Partner Visa Categories (Question No. 2784) Mr Price asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 24 November 2003: (1) What action has been taken to reduce or eliminate serial sponsorships of brides or partners.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question, based on advice from(2) To what extent can the Minister say they have been effective. (3) Is there any scrutiny of Visitors Visas to detect the potential for serial sponsorship. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) On coming into office in 1996, this Government, in response to growing concerns about abuse of the partner visa categories as an avenue for people to gain permanent residence in Australia, introduced a package of measures limiting the number of sponsorships that may be lodged by people sponsoring a spouse, prospective spouse or interdependent partner. This package provides that: the number of approved spouse, prospective spouse or interdependency sponsorships are limited to two per person, a minimum of five years apart (approved sponsorships are those which resulted in the grant of any spouse, prospective spouse or interdependency visa, irrespective of when the visa was applied for); people who have been sponsored as a spouse, prospective spouse or interdependent partner will be restricted from sponsoring a partner under one of these visa classes for five years, counted from the date their application was lodged; a woman granted a Woman at Risk (Subclass 204) visa will not be able to sponsor a former spouse from whom she declared she was divorced or permanently separated prior to the grant of the visa, or who was not declared in her visa application, for a period of five years; and the total number of people that may ever be sponsored by one person in any of these subclasses is two. In support of this package, my Department has also introduced a range of measures to minimise possible misuse of the partner visa process, including: The introduction of a Best Practice Model for processing partner visa applications. The Model was introduced in Australian offices in 1999 and subsequently at overseas offices in November 2001. It aims to reduce partner visa processing times and enhance integrity of the program. The establishment of specialist Bona Fides Units (BFUs) in all Australian offices at the beginning of 2002, to undertake more intensive checking in cases where possible fraud has been identified. Benefits flowing directly from the establishment of the BFUs are already apparent. They include: better reporting on emerging fraud trends; greater cooperation between Australian and overseas offices in the identification and prevention of immigration fraud; and checks of onshore sponsors on behalf of overseas offices, leading to the discovery of non-bona fide applications where the sponsor was found to be living with another partner. A requirement that at least 85% of Spouse visa applicants, and all applicants for a Partner visa on the basis of a de facto or interdependent relationship, are interviewed. My Department is also working towards progressively improving departmental IT systems to facilitate better monitoring of people who sponsor visa applicants. (2) While the legislation does not allow a person to sponsor more than two partner visa applicants in their lifetime, there remains the possibility that a sponsor may seek to avoid identification as a previous sponsor by provision of misleading information. My Department closely monitors the partner visa caseload and decision-makers have the facility to cross-check departmental records for information concerning any previous sponsorships by a particular sponsor. My Department is also continually refining its processes to ensure that the risk of sponsors breaching the limitation on sponsorship is minimised.

theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous AffairsInformation available to my Department indicates that the implementation of the sponsorship limitation provisions has been very successful in preventing sponsorship beyond the limit provided in the legislation. (3) Where an applicant for a Visitor visa declares an intention to be visiting an Australian citizen or permanent resident who has previously sponsored at least two persons on Partner visas, this is a matter that would be closely scrutinised in terms of whether a genuine visit was intended. However, not all Visitor visa applicants would necessarily declare the names of all the persons they were intending to visit while in Australia. At a more generic level, it should be noted that: The non-return rate for visitors coming to Australia has fallen very significantly over recent years while at the same time the approval rate has increased; and The rate at which visitors are applying for Partner visas after entering as visitors has also declined. (2) Can the Minister say whether there have been staff cutbacks in the Department’s Public Access Unit at any time during the financial years ending (a) 30 June 2002, and (b) 30 June 2003; if so, (i) when did these staff cutbacks occur, and (ii) why. (3) What were the staffing levels in the Public Access Unit immediately prior to any cutbacks during the financial years ended 30 June 2002 and 2003 and what is the staffing level of the Public Access Unit now. (4) What was the total number of requests to the Department under the FOI Act for the financial year ended 30 June (a) 2001, (b) 2002, and (c) 2003. (5) What was the average processing time for FOI requests during the financial year ended 30 June (a) 2001, (b) 2002, and (c) 2003. (6) What is the current average processing time of FOI requests. (7) Is the Minister able to say whether a failure to respond to an FOI request within 30 days is a breach of the FOI Act. (8) What steps is the Minister taking in respect of staffing levels to ensure that FOI requests are processed within the statutory time period of 30 days. The Department is unable to comment
