Year Type of Request Average Processing Days 2003-2004 Access 33 Amendment 99 Annotation 0 All 36.3 (7) Section 15 of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 sets out statutory time frames for a response by the Minister or an agency to an FOI request which has been made in the proper form. Subsection 15(5) provides that the Minister or agency must: within 14 days (if not earlier) take all reasonable steps to notify the requestor that the request has been received; and as soon as practicable, but in any case by the end of 30 days from when the request is received, take all reasonable steps to notify the applicant of a decision on the request (including a decision under s21 of the Act to defer provision of the document). Section 15(6) provides that the Minister or agency may extend the period for a decision by a further 30 days when the requested documents are likely to affect Commonwealth-State relations, relate to business affairs or contain personal information of a third party. The applicant must be advised of any such extension as soon as practicable. Section 31 of the Act provides that certain periods are to be disregarded for the purposes of processing requests. The fact that an FOI request has not been decided within 30 days of receipt does not necessarily mean that the legislative requirements have not been met. (8) As part of its ongoing commitment to client service and process improvement, the Department is developing a centralised FOI processing unit. The centralised unit is expected to facilitate the development of staff expertise in FOI processing and provide greater responsiveness in caseload management. To date, the Department’s central office has taken over processing FOI requests that previously would have been done in the ACT, NT, Tasmania and SA offices. Transfer of the FOI function from Qld and WA offices will take place over the next few months. In all cases, the state/territory offices remain responsible for finalising their existing FOI cases. New South Wales and Victoria offices will continue processing FOI requests due to the high volume of FOI applications received in these states and the costs that would be involved in transferring the files to central office. This will be re-evaluated in the future, following trial of a system for scanning files to CD-ROM. (9) The purpose of the proposed Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents Integrity Measures) Bill 2004 is to strengthen and improve the regulation of migration agents. These amendments are necessary to ensure that the Migration Agents Registration Authority (MARA) has adequate powers to protect consumers and that migration agents operate ethically, professionally and competently when assisting people to come to or stay in Australia. It will provide the MARA with new powers to sanction migration agents, particularly those agents who lodge a high number of vexatious, unfounded or incomplete applications. The Senate inquiry into the Bill was finalised in December 2003, with the Committee suggesting some further amendments to the proposed Bill. The Bill will now be reintroduced into the Senate in February 2004 for enactment. The Department understands the honourable member’s question as being whether a migration agent could be disciplined under the proposed powers if: the agent has multiple failures of visa applications due to incomplete applications; and those applications were incomplete due to the Department not meeting the processing times set out in the FOI Act. Decisions under the Migration Act 1958 and the Freedom of Information Act 1982 are separate and independent. However, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs’ (DIMIA’s) policy is that if an FOI applicant has a substantive visa application under consideration, the Department will endeavour to process the FOI before finalising the substantive visa application. Nevertheless, as detailed in the Department’s FOI Handbook, there are circumstances where request, such as when: access to all the documents requested through FOI has already been given; the decision maker is required by law to finalise the substantive application within a statutory time limit; the applicant is in immigration detention, and processing the FOI request alone either protracts the period a person spends in detention or puts greater pressure on the decision maker to release the detainee against their better judgement; the FOI applicant has agreed that the substantive application should be decided first and a speedy decision is possible. Immigration: Migration Related Decisions (Question No. 2820) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 1 December 2003: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2186 (Hansard, 13 October 2003, page 21279) in respect of the application of section 5 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (ADJR) to decisions of an administrative character under the Migration Act 1958 that are not privative clause decisions within the meaning of subsection 474(2) of the Migration Act, is the Minister aware of the judgment of the High Court of Australia in R v Hickman; Ex parte Fox and Clinton (1945) 70 CLR 598. (2) Notwithstanding the privative clause provision in section 474 of the Migration Act, does section 5 still permit judicial review of decisions in which it can be established that there exists (a) Jurisdictional error, (b) Mala Fides, and (c) Constitutional Grounds. (3) Are there any other grounds known to the Minister in which the provisions of section 5 of the ADJR Act apply notwithstanding the provision of section 474 Migration Act; if so, what are they. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) I am aware of the decision of the High Court of Australia in R v Hickman; Ex parte Fox and Clinton (1945) 70 CLR 598. (2) and (3) Paragraph (da) of Schedule1 to the ADJR Act excludes a privative clause decision within the meaning of subsection 474(2) of the Migration Act from those decisions to which the ADJR Act applies. This has the effect of restricting the jurisdiction of the Federal Court and the Federal Magistrates Court under the ADJR Act in respect of migration decisions to those decisions set out in subsection 474(4) of the Migration Act and any decisions specified in regulation made under subsection 474(5). Whether a particular decision made under the Migration Act would be excluded from judicial review would be a matter for the Court to determine. Veterans: Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service (Question No. 2872) Mr Katter asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 4 December 2003: (1) Is he aware of an initiative by a group of Vietnam veterans who have established on Kalpower Station a respite area known as Pandanus Park for the use of all returned war veterans. (2) Is he aware of reports that, in contrast to many government counselling services, this project is producing beneficial outcomes for the physiological well-being and mental health of veterans. (3) Would the Government consider purchasing Kalpower Station from the Queensland Government, which intends to embark on a course that would preclude such a handover, and arranging for it to be held in trust for Vietnam veterans and returned servicemen from other wars. (1) I have not received any formal representations on this specific initiative. I am advised that the initiative has been brought to the attention of the office of the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, the Hon Danna Vale MP. (2) I am not aware of any reports regarding the mental health outcomes of the Pandanus Project. However the government’s many counselling services for veterans are in fact of great benefit. For example the Vietnam Veteran Counselling Service (VVCS) is a specialised, free, confidential service for all veterans and serving Australian Defence Force personnel. The VVCS has recently expanded and its success is evidenced by the year on year increasing numbers of veterans participating in the counselling, and recent surveys indicating high satisfaction levels amongst veterans. (3) I am advised that the Queensland Government purchased the land in 1995. I further understand that the Queensland Government has offered alternative sites to the veterans, all of which have been turned down. It is inappropriate for the Australian Government to comment on the future use of the land as current control lies with the State of Queensland.
